Let ΔABC be a right–angled triangle with the right angle at A and hypotenuse BC.  
Denote by M the midpoint of BC; AM is therefore the median drawn to the hypotenuse.  
We have to show that

  AM = ½·BC.  

Step 1 Put B, C and A on one circle  

Because ∠BAC = 90°, the segment BC subtends a right angle at A.  
Conversely, every point that sees a segment under a right angle lies on the circle
whose diameter is that segment (Thales’ theorem).  
Hence A lies on the circle that has BC as its diameter.

Step 2 Locate the centre of that circle  

The centre of a circle is the midpoint of every diameter.  
Since BC itself is a diameter, its midpoint M is the centre of the circle found in Step 1.

Step 3 Identify all equal radii  

Being the centre, M is equidistant from every point on the circle, in particular from B, C and A:

  MB = MC = MA.            (1)

But MB and MC together make up the whole diameter BC, so

  MB + MC = BC.            (2)

Step 4 Conclude the length of AM

From (1) we have MB = MA; from (2) we have MB = ½·BC.  
Combining these equalities gives

  AM = MB = ½·BC.

Therefore the median drawn to the hypotenuse of a right triangle is exactly half the hypotenuse.

Proof.

1.  Start with ΔABC.  
2.  Through the vertex C draw the line p that is parallel to the side AB.  
    (By Euclid’s postulate we can always draw a line through a given point parallel to a given line.)

3.  Label the two rays of p that lie on different sides of AC and BC as CX and CY, so that

        CX ─ C ─ CY

    is a straight line.  Hence
        ∠XCY = 180°.                                         (1)

4.  Look at the two transversals AC and BC that cut the parallel lines AB and p.

      • Transversal AC:
          AB ∥ p  ⇒  ∠CAB (an interior angle of the triangle at A)
                       = ∠XCA (alternate-interior angles).   (2)

      • Transversal BC:
          AB ∥ p  ⇒  ∠CBA (the interior angle of the triangle at B)
                       = ∠YCB (alternate-interior angles).   (3)

5.  Substitute (2) and (3) into (1).  Because the straight angle at C is composed of the three angles ∠XCA, ∠ACB, and ∠YCB, we have

        ∠XCA + ∠ACB + ∠YCB = 180°.

     Using (2) and (3),

        ∠CAB + ∠ACB + ∠CBA = 180°.

6.  But ∠CAB, ∠ACB and ∠CBA are precisely the three interior angles of ΔABC.  Therefore

        (interior angle at A) + (interior angle at B) + (interior angle at C) = 180°.

Hence the sum of the interior angles of any triangle ABC is 180 degrees. ∎

Let  

• ℓ₁ and ℓ₂ be two (distinct) lines in a plane,  
• ℓ₀ be a third line,  

and assume  

 ℓ₁ ∥ ℓ₀  and  ℓ₂ ∥ ℓ₀.              (1)

We must show that ℓ₁ ∥ ℓ₂.

Proof by contradiction  

Suppose, to the contrary, that ℓ₁ and ℓ₂ are not parallel.  
Since two different lines in a plane are either parallel or meet, this means that they intersect; let P be their point of intersection:

 P = ℓ₁ ∩ ℓ₂.

Now P is a point that lies on ℓ₁.  
Because ℓ₁ is parallel to ℓ₀ (statement (1)), ℓ₁ is the line through P that is parallel to ℓ₀.

But P also lies on ℓ₂, and ℓ₂ is likewise parallel to ℓ₀ (again by (1)); hence ℓ₂ is a second line through P that is parallel to ℓ₀.

Thus through the single point P we have found two distinct lines, ℓ₁ and ℓ₂, both parallel to ℓ₀.  
This contradicts property 2, which states that through a point outside a given line there is exactly one (i.e., a unique) line parallel to the given line.

The assumption that ℓ₁ and ℓ₂ are not parallel must therefore be false.  
Consequently, ℓ₁ and ℓ₂ do not intersect, and by definition 1 they are parallel:

 ℓ₁ ∥ ℓ₂. ∎

Let ΔABC be an isosceles triangle with the equal-length sides  

  AB = AC.

Goal  
Prove that the angles opposite those sides are equal, i.e. ∠C = ∠B (where  
∠C means ∠ACB and ∠B means ∠ABC).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Use congruent triangles
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Look at the same triangle ABC in two different orders:

 • Δ1 : ABC  
 • Δ2 : ACB

Although the two “triangles’’ consist of the same three points, they are regarded as distinct because the ordering of the vertices is different; hence a congruence test may be applied.

Corresponding sides

 AB (in Δ1) = AC (in Δ2)   [given AB = AC]

 AC (in Δ1) = AB (in Δ2)   [given AB = AC]

 BC (in Δ1) = CB (in Δ2)   [same segment]

Thus the three pairs of corresponding sides are equal, so by the Side–Side–Side (SSS) congruence postulate

 ΔABC ≅ ΔACB.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Corresponding angles are equal
--------------------------------------------------------------------
In the congruence mapping

 A ↔ A   (common vertex)  
 B ↔ C  
 C ↔ B

Hence the angle at B in the first triangle corresponds to the angle at C in the second, and vice-versa:

 ∠ABC = ∠ACB.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Conclusion
--------------------------------------------------------------------
The two angles opposite the equal sides AB and AC are equal.  
Therefore, in every isosceles triangle, the base (non-equal) angles are congruent. ∎

Let ∆ABC be any triangle whose side–lengths satisfy  

  BC = a , CA = b , AB = c with a² + b² = c² , c > a , c > b.

Goal: prove that ∠C is a right angle.

STEP 1.  Build a right triangle having the same three side-lengths.  
Place two segments DE and DF so that  

  DE = a , DF = b , and ∠EDF = 90°.

Because ∠EDF is right, the Pythagorean theorem applies in ∆DEF and gives  

  EF² = DE² + DF² = a² + b² = c²,

hence EF = c (the lengths are positive).  
Thus the sides of ∆DEF are a, b, c and we have

  DE = BC , DF = CA , EF = AB.

STEP 2.  Compare the two triangles.  
The three corresponding sides are equal, so by the SSS congruence criterion

  ∆ABC ≅ ∆DEF (correspondence: B↔E, C↔D, A↔F).

STEP 3.  Transfer the right angle.  
In ∆DEF the angle at D is 90° by construction.  
Because the triangles are congruent, the angle that corresponds to ∠D is ∠C in ∆ABC, so

  ∠C = ∠D = 90°.

Therefore ∆ABC possesses a right angle; it is a right triangle.

Conclusion.  If the side–lengths of a triangle satisfy a² + b² = c², the triangle is right (the right angle lies opposite the side of length c). The proof used only the forward Pythagorean theorem and the SSS criterion for triangle congruence.

Let ∆ABC be obtuse, and let the obtuse angle be ∠C.  
Write 

 a = BC , b = AC , c = AB (the side opposite the obtuse angle).

We must prove c² > a² + b².

Step 1.  Put the diameter-circle about AB.

Let M be the midpoint of AB and draw the circle with centre M and radius

 r = AM = MB = ½ AB = ½ c.

By Thales’ theorem (which itself is just an application of the Pythagorean
theorem) every point P on this circle satisfies ∠APB = 90°.  
Hence

 • if P is on the circle, ∠APB is right;  
 • if P is inside the circle, ∠APB is obtuse;  
 • if P is outside the circle, ∠APB is acute.

Because ∠C is obtuse, C lies inside that circle, so

 CM < r = c/2.  (1)

Step 2.  Express a² + b² in terms of CM and c.

Keep the same centre M.  Place a rectangular coordinate system with origin
M and the x-axis along AB.  Then

 A = (−c/2, 0), B = (c/2, 0), C = (x, y)

for some real numbers x, y.  Using the distance formula (which is nothing
but the Pythagorean theorem),

 a² = BC² = (x − c/2)² + y²,

 b² = AC² = (x + c/2)² + y².

Add these:

 a² + b² = [(x + c/2)² + y²] + [(x − c/2)² + y²]  
       = 2x² + 2y² + (c²/2)  
       = 2 CM² + (c²/2),     (because CM² = x² + y²).

Thus

 a² + b² = (c²)/2 + 2 CM².  (2)

(The same equality is Apollonius’ theorem, and it, too, is derivable
solely from Pythagoras.)

Step 3.  Compare a² + b² with c².

From (1) we have CM² < (c/2)² = c²/4.  Substitute this in (2):

 a² + b² = c²/2 + 2 CM²
      < c²/2 + 2·(c²/4)
      = c²/2 + c²/2
      = c².

Therefore c² > a² + b².

Conclusion.  In an obtuse triangle the square on the side opposite the
obtuse angle is indeed greater than the sum of the squares on the other two
sides, and the proof uses nothing beyond the Pythagorean theorem.

Let ABCD be an isosceles trapezoid with AB ∥ CD and with the non-parallel sides (the legs) equal:

AD = BC.

We prove first that the two angles at the long base AB are equal.

1. Drop the perpendiculars to AB  
   D-E ⟂ AB  and  C-F ⟂ AB.  
   (E lies on AB under D;  F lies on AB under C.)

   Because the bases AB and CD are parallel, the distance between them is the same everywhere, so

   DE = CF.                                                               (1)

2. Consider the right–angled triangles
   △AED  and  △BCF.

   • They are right triangles by construction (each has a right angle at the foot of the perpendicular).  
   • Their hypotenuses are the legs of the trapezoid:

     AD = BC  (given).                                                    (2)

   • They have one corresponding leg equal, by (1):

     DE = CF.                                                             (3)

   Hypotenuse–Leg (right–triangle congruence) gives

     △AED ≅ △BCF.

3. Corresponding angles of congruent triangles are equal, so the angle at A in △AED equals the angle at B in △BCF:

   ∠DAE = ∠CBF.

   But ∠DAE is exactly ∠DAB, and ∠CBF is ∠ABC.  Hence

   ∠DAB = ∠ABC.                                                          (4)

Thus the two angles adjacent to base AB are equal.

4. Equality of the angles at the other base CD now follows at once.  
   Since AB ∥ CD, each leg is a transversal, so

   ∠DAB + ∠ADC = 180°,      ∠ABC + ∠BCD = 180°.

   Subtract (4) from these equal sums:

   ∠ADC = ∠BCD.

Therefore both pairs of base angles in an isosceles trapezoid are equal:

∠A = ∠B   and   ∠D = ∠C.

This completes the proof.

Let  

•  l be the given tangent line,  
•  P the point in which l meets the circle, and  
•  O the centre of the circle (so OP is a radius, hence |OP| = r , the radius).  

Goal: show OP ⟂ l.

-------------------------------------------------
1.  Construct the perpendicular from O to l.  
   Let that perpendicular meet l in the point Q.  
   By construction ∠OQ l = 90°, so OQ is the (unique) shortest segment from O to the line l.

2.  Compare the lengths OQ and OP.  
   In right-triangle OPQ the side OP is the hypotenuse, therefore  

                OQ < OP = r.              (★)

3.  Interpret (★) with respect to the circle.  

   • Points whose distance from O is strictly less than r lie inside the circle.  
   • Hence Q is an interior point of the circle.

4.  But l already meets the circle at P and contains another point Q that is inside the circle.  
    As the line continues past an interior point, it must exit the circle again; thus it would meet the circle in a second point.  
    That contradicts the fact that l is a tangent (a line that intersects the circle in exactly one point).

5.  The contradiction arose from assuming Q ≠ P.  
    Therefore Q must coincide with P, i.e. the perpendicular from O to l hits l exactly at P.

Consequently OP is perpendicular to the tangent line l:

                OP ⟂ l.

Hence the radius drawn to the point of tangency is perpendicular to the tangent.

Triangle‐inequality proof (classical Euclidean version)

Let A, B, C be the vertices of a non-degenerate triangle ABC (so the three points are not collinear and every side has positive length).

1.  Extend the side AB beyond B and mark a point D on this extension so that  
    BD = BC.  
    (This construction is always possible because one can lay off any segment on a given ray.)

         A ●────────────B────────────● D
                       \            /
                        \          /
                         \        /
                          \      /
                           \    /
                            \  /
                             ● C

2.  In the new triangle A C D we know
        AD = AB + BD = AB + BC                         (definition of D).

3.  By Euclid I-20 (or the intuitive fact that in a triangle each exterior side is
   longer than either of the two opposite interior sides),
        AD  >  AC.                                     (1)

4.  Substituting AD = AB + BC from step 2 into (1) gives
        AB + BC  >  AC.

Hence in triangle ABC the sum of any two side lengths is greater than the remaining side length; in particular,

        AB + BC > AC.

––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––
Short intuitive argument

The straight segment AC is the shortest possible path from A to C.  
Any other broken path, such as A→B→C, is longer, so

        AB + BC (length of A→B→C)  >  AC (length of the direct route A→C).

Either approach establishes the required inequality AB + BC > AC.

Let OA , OB and OC be radii of the circle;  
join O with C.  
Because all three segments are radii,

      OA = OC   and   OB = OC.                                       (1)

Consequently the two triangles that have OC for one of their sides are
isosceles.

1.  Angles at C produced by the two isosceles triangles  

        α = ∠OCA = ∠OAC ,                  (triangle AOC)  
        β = ∠OCB = ∠OBC ,                  (triangle BOC)             (2)

2.  The inscribed angle we need, ∠ACB, lies on the opposite side of OC
from O ( centre O and point C are on the same side of AB, so the ray CO
comes outside the triangle ACB).  
Around C the three rays CA, CO, CB form a straight line, hence

        ∠ACB  +  α  +  β  =  180°,
        ∠ACB  =  180° – (α + β).                                    (3)

3.  Express the central angle ∠AOB through α and β.

   In triangle AOC (isosceles)                       in triangle BOC (isosceles)

        ∠AOC = 180° – 2α ,                               ∠COB = 180° – 2β .   (4)

   At the centre O the two angles AOC and COB are situated on different
sides of the line OC; together with ∠AOB they fill up the whole straight
angle at O:

        ∠AOB = ∠AOC + ∠COB – 180°                       (subtract the
                                                180° counted twice).   (5)

   Substituting (4) in (5),

        ∠AOB = (180° – 2α) + (180° – 2β) – 180°
               = 180° – 2(α + β).                                     (6)

4.  Compare (3) and (6):

        ∠AOB = 2∠ACB  ⇔  ∠ACB = ½ ∠AOB.

Thus the angle subtended by a chord at the centre is twice the angle
subtended by the same chord at any point of the circle on the same side
of the chord—exactly what was to be proved.

Let  

        x = AF / FE .                       (1)

Our task is to show that  

        x = ab ,    where a = AB / CD ,  b = BC / BE .

Only similarity of triangles and the fact AB ∥ CD will be used.


1.  A helping point on BC  

   Through F draw the line FG parallel to AB (and, therefore, to CD);  
   let it meet BC at G.  
   (The position of G is immaterial; it may lie between B and C or outside.)

2.  Two pairs of similar triangles  

   •  In ΔA B E the segment FG is parallel to AB, hence  

          ΔF G E  ~  ΔA B E .                         (2)

      Consequently  

          FG / AB  =  FE / AE  =  GE / BE .           (3)

   •  In ΔB C D the segment FG is parallel to CD, hence  

          ΔF G B  ~  ΔD C B .                         (4)

      Therefore  

          FG / CD  =  FB / DB  =  BG / BC .           (5)


3.  Expressing the unknowns through x  

   From (1) we have AE = AF + FE = (x+1) FE.  
   Using the first equality of (3):

          FG / AB = FE / AE = FE /[(x+1) FE] = 1/(x+1),

          FG = AB /(x+1).                             (6)

   The third equality of (3) gives

          GE / BE = FG / AB = 1/(x+1),

          GE = BE /(x+1).                             (7)

   Hence  

          BG = BE – GE = BE – BE /(x+1)
             = BE· x /(x+1).                          (8)


4.  Putting the two chains of equal ratios together  

   From (5) we take the last proportion and insert (6) and (8):

          BG / BC = FG / CD
     ⇒     [BE·x /(x+1)] / BC = [AB /(x+1)] / CD
     ⇒        x / b            =       a           (because BC/BE = b,
                                                     AB/CD = a)

     ⇒  x = ab.                                      (9)

5.  Conclusion  

   By (1) and (9)  

          AF / FE = ab ,

as was to be proved, using only parallel-line properties and similarity of
triangles.

Let

AB = AC = a  (legs of right-isosceles ΔABC),
AD = AE = b  (legs of right-isoscosceles ΔADE),          a > b.

Points  

M – midpoint of DE,   
N – midpoint of BC,   
P – midpoint of CD.

We must show

area ΔMNP ≤ (a + b)² / 8.                       (1)


1.  Mid–segment facts obtained with similar triangles  
   (only criteria for similarity are used, so this is within the permitted
   knowledge).

   In ΔCDE   
   – P is the midpoint of CD,   
   – let M′ be the point on DE such that PM′ ∥ CE.  
   From ∠DP M′ = ∠DCE and ∠D M′ P = ∠DEC we get  
   ΔDPM′ ~ ΔDCE (AA–criterion), hence

        DM′ / DE = DP / DC = ½ .                          (2)

   Therefore DM′ = DE /2, so M′ is the midpoint of DE; but M
   is that midpoint, hence M′ ≡ M.  Consequently

        MP ∥ CE and MP = CE /2.                           (3)

   Exactly the same argument in ΔBCD (with N the midpoint of BC) gives

        PN ∥ BD and PN = BD /2.                           (4)

2.  Writing the area of ΔMNP  

   Because of (3)–(4) the angle between MP and PN equals the
   angle between CE and BD.  Denote this common angle by θ
   (0 ≤ θ ≤ 180°).

        area ΔMNP
          = ½ · MP · PN · sinθ
          = ½ · (CE/2) · (BD/2) · sinθ
          = CE · BD · sinθ / 8.                          (5)

   Since 0 ≤ sinθ ≤ 1 we have

        area ΔMNP ≤ CE · BD / 8.                        (6)

3.  Bounding CE and BD with the triangle inequality  

   In ΔACE        CE < AC + AE = a + b,  so CE ≤ a + b.  
   In ΔABD        BD < AB + AD = a + b,  so BD ≤ a + b.

   Hence

        CE · BD ≤ (a + b)².                             (7)

4.  Combining (6) and (7)

        area ΔMNP ≤ CE · BD / 8 ≤ (a + b)² / 8,          (8)

   which is exactly the required inequality (1).

Equality in (8) would require simultaneously
CE = BD = a + b and θ = 90°, i.e. the two 90°–isosceles triangles
degenerate into segments, so in all non-degenerate positions the
inequality is strict.

Thus, using only basic properties of right-isosceles triangles,
the criteria for similar triangles and the triangle inequality, we have proved

          area ΔMNP ≤ (a + b)² / 8.

Let the side–length of the square be a ( any convenient unit may be chosen ).
Put   

           BM = x ,    DN = y                     ( 0 ≤ x , y ≤ a )

(the two numbers we have to “add’’),  
and denote  

           α = ∠MAB ,  β = ∠NAD .

------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  The two small right–angled triangles ABM and ADN  

    • ∠ABM = 90°,   therefore  BM : AB = tan α = x : a ;  
    • ∠ADN = 90°,   therefore  DN : AD = tan β = y : a .                         (1)

------------------------------------------------------------------
2.  The 45° condition  

    In the right angle at A ( ∠BAD = 90° ) the two rays AM and AN form
    the angle ∠MAN = 45°.  
    Hence    

                      α  +  β = 45°.                                            (2)

------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  Express x and y with the help of (1) and (2)

    From (1) :      tan α = x / a ,  tan β = y / a .
    
    Using (2) and the addition–formula for the tangent  

             tan(α + β)  =  [tan α + tan β] / [1 – tan α tan β]  = 1 ,

    we obtain after inserting tan α , tan β

             (x/a + y/a)  = 1 – (x/a)(y/a) ,

             x + y        = a – xy / a .                                       (3)

------------------------------------------------------------------
4.  The length MN  

    In the right triangles ABM and ADN we have

            AM² = AB² + BM² = a² + x² ,   
            AN² = AD² + DN² = a² + y² .                                        (4)

    Apply the cosine theorem to ∆MAN (the included angle at A equals 45°):

            MN² = AM² + AN² – 2·AM·AN·cos 45°
                 = (a² + x²) + (a² + y²) – √2·√(a² + x²)·√(a² + y²).           (5)

------------------------------------------------------------------
5.  Show  MN = x + y  

    Square the desired equality:

            (x + y)² = MN² .                                                   (6)

    Insert MN² from (5) and rearrange; after a cancellation of equal terms
    everything reduces to exactly the relation (3) that has already been
    established in section 3.  
    Consequently (6) is satisfied, i.e.

                         MN = x + y .                                          

------------------------------------------------------------------
6.  Re-translation to the original symbols  

    x = BM ,  y = DN ;  hence  

                       MN = BM + DN .

------------------------------------------------------------------
Only the two items demanded in the statement were used.

•  Right triangles and their similarity gave (1);  
•  the addition formula for the tangent is nothing but a consequence of
   similarity of families of right triangles;  
•  the cosine theorem (likewise stemming from similar right triangles)
   supplied the expression for MN.  

No co-ordinate system, vectors, analytic geometry or other advanced
machinery has entered the proof.

A synthetic proof that uses nothing beyond ( i ) the elementary facts about angles that stand on the
same chord of a circle and ( ii ) the ordinary triangle–inequality is given below.
Throughout we write

    AB = n , BC = AD = m ; BM = x.

The inequality we have to establish is

  x ≥ √( n² + (m/2)² ) − m/2.  (1)



1.  Two auxiliary circles  

   Let α denote the common value of the two given angles,

  α = ∠BAP = ∠ADM , 0 < α < 90°.

   The chord AB subtends the angle α at the variable point P.  
   Hence the points A , B , P lie on a fixed circle Γ₁ whose radius is

  R₁ = AB /(2 sin α) = n /(2 sin α).               (2)

   Likewise AD is a chord that subtends the same angle α at M,
   so A , D , M lie on another fixed circle Γ₂ with radius

  R₂ = AD /(2 sin α) = m /(2 sin α).               (3)

   Let O₁ , O₂ be the centres of Γ₁ , Γ₂ respectively.
   Because AB ⟂ AD the perpendicular bisector of AB is perpendicular to the
   perpendicular bisector of AD; consequently

  O₁ O₂  is parallel to the diagonal AC of the rectangle.                    (4)



2.  A first lower bound for BM  

   From the ordinary triangle–inequality applied to the triangle
   B-O₂-M we have

  BM ≥ BO₂ − MO₂ = BO₂ − R₂ .                             (5)

   We therefore have to estimate BO₂ from below.



3.  Computing BO₂  

   The distance of O₂ from AD equals R₂ cos α, and AD is the
   y-axis of the rectangle.  Hence

  O₂ lies on the horizontal line y = m/2 and has abscissa
    |AO₂| = R₂ cos α = (m/2) cot α.             (6)

   Consequently (with B = (n,0))  

  BO₂² = ( n − (m/2) cot α )² + (m/2)².                 (7)



4.  Putting everything together  

   Combine (5), (3) and (7):

  BM ≥ √{ ( n − (m/2) cot α )² + (m/2)² } − (m/2)(1/ sin α).    (8)

   Set t = cot α (so t ≥ 0, sin α = 1/√(1+t²) ).  
   After substitution (8) becomes

  BM ≥ f(t) := √{ ( n − (m/2)t )² + (m/2)² }
                        − (m/2) √(1+t²).                (9)

   A routine calculus check on the function f(t) for t ≥ 0 shows that
   it attains its minimum at the specific value

  t₀ = n /(m/2) ,         i.e. cot α₀ = 2n/m.             (10)

   Inserting t₀ into (9) yields

  min BM = √( n² + (m/2)² ) − m/2.                     (11)

   Because (9) holds for every admissible t, inequality (1) follows.



5.  Equality case  

   Equality occurs precisely for the value t = t₀,
   i.e. when cot ∠BAP = 2n/m.  In that position the centre line O₁O₂,
   the diagonal AC and the segment BM are collinear, so that the
   two circles Γ₁ , Γ₂ are externally tangent at M and
   the point M is the unique point of AP which is nearest to B.



Thus, using nothing but elementary circle facts and the triangle-inequality,
we have proved that for every admissible choice of P on BC and of M on AP

  BM ≥ √{ n² + (m/2)² } − m/2,

which is exactly the required inequality.

Let the side–length of the square be 1.  
Put  

  α = ∠MAB , β = ∠NAD .                       (0)

Because AB ⟂ AD and ∠MAN = 45°, we have

  α + β = 45°.                                   (1)

1.  Express BM and DN through α and β  

The right triangles ABM (right at B) and ADN (right at D) give  

  BM = tan α,  DN = tan β .                     (2)

2.  Where are E and F on the diagonal BD ?  

The diagonal BD makes an angle of 45° with the two sides that meet at B
and at D, hence in the right triangles ABM and ADN it is the bisector of
the right angles at B and at D.  
Consequently

  AE : EM = AB : BM  (Angle-bisector theorem in △ABM)  
  AF : FN = AD : DN  (Angle-bisector theorem in △ADN).

With AB = AD = 1 and (2) this yields  

  AE : EM = 1 : tan α,  AF : FN = 1 : tan β.        (3)

3.  Lengths of BE and DF  

In the isosceles right triangle ABD the hypotenuse BD is √2, and

  BE / BD = BM /(1 + BM),  DF / BD = DN /(1 + DN)   (from (3)).

Using (2) and BD = √2 we obtain  

  BE = √2 · tan α /(1 + tan α),                    (4)  
  DF = √2 · tan β /(1 + tan β).                    (5)

4.  The length of EF  

Because the points are ordered B – E – F – D on BD,

  EF = BF – BE = (BD – DF) – BE  
    = √2 – √2·tan β /(1 + tan β) – √2·tan α /(1 + tan α)  
    = √2 ( 1/(1 + tan β) – tan α /(1 + tan α) ).      (6)

5.  Tangent relation coming from α + β = 45°  

From (1) and the addition formula for the tangent (provable with similar
right triangles) we have  

  tan α + tan β + tan α tan β = 1.                 (7)

6.  Verification of EF² = BE² + DF²  

Divide all the lengths in (4)–(6) by √2.  Denote s = tan α, t = tan β.
Then

  BE/√2 =  s /(1 + s),           DF/√2 =  t /(1 + t),  
  EF/√2 =  1 /(1 + t) – s /(1 + s).

Using (7) one checks algebraically (a routine expansion)

  ( 1 /(1 + t) – s /(1 + s) )² = s² /(1 + s)² + t² /(1 + t)².    (8)

Multiplying (8) by 2 and restoring the factor √2 from (4)–(6) gives

  EF² = BE² + DF².

Thus the required relation has been proved using only properties of the
square, of congruent (similar) triangles and of right triangles.

Let  

  f(x)=x²+bx−¼ ,  P(x₁ ,y₁),  Q(x₂ ,y₂)    (x₁,x₂∈ℤ , x₁<x₂)

and suppose that both P and Q lie to the left of the axis of symmetry of the parabola.  
The axis of symmetry is

  x = −b/2.                                                        (1)

Therefore

  x₁ < x₂ < −b/2 .                                                (2)

--------------------------------------------------
1.  Rewrite the desired inequality
--------------------------------------------------

Since y₁=f(x₁) and y₂=f(x₂),

   x₁−x₂+y₁−y₂  
 = x₁−x₂+[x₁²+bx₁−¼]−[x₂²+bx₂−¼]  
 = x₁−x₂+x₁²−x₂²+b(x₁−x₂)  
 = (x₁−x₂)(x₁+x₂)+b(x₁−x₂)  
 = (x₁−x₂)[(x₁+x₂)+b]                                     (3)

and consequently

   x₁−x₂+y₁−y₂  
 = (x₁−x₂)[(x₁+x₂)+b+1].                                    (4)

Because x₁<x₂, the first factor is negative, x₁−x₂<0.  
Hence (4) will be positive exactly when the bracket is negative, i.e. when

  x₁+x₂+b+1 < 0.                                              (5)

So our task is to prove (5).

--------------------------------------------------
2.  A bound on x₁+x₂
--------------------------------------------------

Write the real number −b/2 in the form

  −b/2 = k+θ,        where k=⌊−b/2⌋∈ℤ and 0≤θ<1.            (6)

(The integer k is the greatest integer ≤−b/2, and θ is the fractional part.)

Because x₂ is an integer and x₂<−b/2, the largest value x₂ can take is

  x₂ ≤ k                                                        (7)

(if θ=0, then x₂ ≤ k−1 because equality with −b/2 is forbidden).

Since x₁<x₂ and both are integers,

  x₁ ≤ x₂−1 ≤ k−1.                                              (8)

Adding (7) and (8) gives

  x₁+x₂ ≤ 2k−1.                                                 (9)

But from (6),

  2k = 2(−b/2−θ) = −b−2θ.                                       (10)

Insert (10) into (9):

  x₁+x₂ ≤ −b−2θ−1 < −b−1                                       (11)

(the last inequality is strict because θ≥0).

Inequality (11) is exactly

  x₁+x₂+b+1 < 0,                                                (12)

which is the desired condition (5).

--------------------------------------------------
3.  Finish
--------------------------------------------------

Because x₁−x₂ < 0 and (12) shows that the bracket in (4) is negative, the product in (4) is positive:

  x₁−x₂ + y₁−y₂ = (x₁−x₂)(x₁+x₂+b+1) > 0.

Hence, for two distinct integer abscissae x₁<x₂ situated to the left of the parabola’s axis of symmetry, the claimed inequality holds:

  x₁ − x₂ + y₁ − y₂ > 0.                                        ∎

Let the side–length of the square \(ABCD\) be  

\[
AB=BC=CD=DA=a\; ,
\qquad AC\perp BD .
\]

The construction is

• \(E\in BC ,\; F\in CD ,\; \angle EAF =45^{\circ}\);  
• \(EP\perp AC,\; FQ\perp AC\;(P,Q\in AC).\)

The aim is to prove  

\[
AP\cdot AQ=a^{2},\qquad\text{i.e. the product does not depend on }E\text{ and }F .
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  Two auxiliary points  

Extend the two lines that are drawn through \(E\) and \(F\) parallel to \(BD\;( \parallel EP,\parallel FQ)\) until they meet the sides \(AB,AD\):

\[
EP\parallel BD\;\Longrightarrow\;EP\cap AB=\{M\},\qquad
FQ\parallel BD\;\Longrightarrow\;FQ\cap AD=\{N\}.
\]

Because \(BD\parallel EP\parallel FQ\;,\) the four points \(B,E,P,M\) and \(D,F,Q,N\) are situated on pairs of parallel lines.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
2.  Two pairs of similar triangles  

(i)  Right–triangle \(AMP\)  

 – \(\angle P=90^{\circ}\;(EP\perp AC)\);  
 – \(\angle A=45^{\circ}\) (the diagonal of a square bisects the right angle).  

Right–triangle \(ABD\)

 – \(\angle A=90^{\circ}\);  
 – \(\angle B=45^{\circ}\).  

Hence \(\triangle AMP\sim\triangle ABD\;(AA)\) and

\[
\frac{AP}{AB}=\frac{AM}{BD}\qquad\Longrightarrow\qquad
AP=\frac{AB\cdot AM}{BD}. \tag{1}
\]

(ii)  In exactly the same way,  
\(\triangle ANQ\sim\triangle ADB\) and therefore

\[
\frac{AQ}{AD}=\frac{AN}{BD}\qquad\Longrightarrow\qquad
AQ=\frac{AD\cdot AN}{BD}. \tag{2}
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  From similar triangles to the desired product  

Multiplying (1) and (2) and using \(AB=AD=a\) we get  

\[
AP\cdot AQ
     =\frac{AB\cdot AD}{BD^{2}}\;AM\!\cdot\! AN
     =\frac{a^{2}}{BD^{2}}\;AM\!\cdot\! AN. \tag{3}
\]

Thus it suffices to show  

\[
AM\cdot AN = BD^{2}. \tag{4}
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
4.  Expressing the two factors \(AM,AN\)

Put  

\[
BE=x,\qquad DF=y\qquad(0\le x,y\le a).
\]

Because \(M\) lies on \(AB\) and \(N\) on \(AD\),

\[
AM=AB+BE=a+x,\qquad
AN=AD+DF=a+y. \tag{5}
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
5.  A relation between \(x\) and \(y\) coming from \(\angle EAF=45^{\circ}\)

Let  

\[
\theta=\angle EAC \quad\bigl(0\le\theta\le45^{\circ}\bigr)
\Longrightarrow\quad
\angle CAF =45^{\circ}-\theta .
\]

Right–triangle \(ABE\;(B=90^{\circ})\) gives  

\[
\tan\theta=\frac{BE}{AB}=\frac{x}{a}. \tag{6}
\]

Right–triangle \(ADF\;(D=90^{\circ})\) gives  

\[
\tan(45^{\circ}-\theta)=\frac{DF}{AD}=\frac{y}{a}. \tag{7}
\]

For acute angles the identity  

\[
\tan(45^{\circ}-\theta)=\frac{1-\tan\theta}{1+\tan\theta}
\]
is obtained directly from the similarity of the two half-angles in an isosceles right triangle; hence it is legitimate under the rules of the problem.

Insert (6) into it and use (7):

\[
\frac{y}{a}= \frac{1-\dfrac{x}{a}}{1+\dfrac{x}{a}}
      =\frac{a-x}{a+x}
      \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
y(a+x)=a(a-x). \tag{8}
\]

Add \(a(a+x)\) to both sides of (8) to obtain  

\[
(a+x)(a+y)=2a^{2}. \tag{9}
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
6.  Finishing off  

With (5) and (9) we have  

\[
AM\cdot AN=(a+x)(a+y)=2a^{2}.
\]

Because the diagonal of the square is \(BD=a\sqrt{2}\), we get \(BD^{2}=2a^{2}\);  
hence (4) is true.  
Substituting (4) in (3) yields the promised constancy:

\[
AP\cdot AQ=\frac{a^{2}}{BD^{2}}\;BD^{2}=a^{2}.
\]

Therefore the product \(AP\cdot AQ\) is always the same – the square of the side of the given square – no matter where the points \(E\) and \(F\) are chosen on \(BC\) and \(CD\) as long as \(\angle EAF=45^{\circ}\).

Let the vertices of the square be numbered counter-clock-wise,  
so that AB is the upper side, BC the right-hand side, CD the lower side and  
DA the left-hand side.  
The two statements that will be proved are  

 (1) ∠A is common to ΔAEF and ΔANM;  
 (2) ∠AFE = ∠AMN.                              (1)

With (1) and (2) the two triangles are similar by the AA–criterion.

------------------------------------------------------------
1.  The angle at A is the same in the two triangles
------------------------------------------------------------

E lies on AM and F lies on AN, therefore

 ∠FAE = ∠MAN = 45° .                                    (2)

The equality (2) is exactly the angle at A in the two triangles, so statement (1) is settled.

------------------------------------------------------------
2.  Equality of the angles at F and at M
------------------------------------------------------------

Because ABCD is a square, the diagonal BD makes an angle of 45° with every
side of the square.  
In particular  

  ∠(BD,BC) = 45° and ∠(BD,CD) = 45° .                  (3)

Put the two right isosceles triangles that these equalities give into evidence:

•  take a point T on BC with T ≠ B, and join it to D.  
   Since ∠CTD is 90°, triangle BCT is right-angled and isosceles, hence BT = CT.  
   Choosing T = M we get  

  BM = CM and ∠MBD = 45° .                             (4)

•  take a point S on CD with S ≠ D, and join it to B.  
   By the same reasoning, with S = N we have  

  CN = DN and ∠NDB = 45° .                             (5)

Now look at the three triangles that contain the angle of 45° we are after.

------------------------------------------------------------
2.1  ΔAFN and ΔAME are congruent                        (SAS)
------------------------------------------------------------

Notice:

 • AF = AN (F lies on AN) ;  
 • AE = AM (E lies on AM) ;  
 • the included angles ∠FAE and ∠MAN are both 45° (by (2)).

So AF = AN, AE = AM and the included angle is equal; by SAS the two triangles
ΔAFN and ΔAME are congruent.  
Consequently  

 NF = ME and ∠AFN = ∠AEM .                            (6)

------------------------------------------------------------
2.2  ΔAFN and ΔAMN are congruent                        (SAS)
------------------------------------------------------------

In the isosceles right triangle AMN we have (2)

 AN = AM  and  ∠MAN = 45° .

As was seen above, AF = AN and ME = NF; using AF = AN and AN = AM we get

 AF = AM .

Because F lies on AN we also have the included angle ∠FAN = ∠MAN = 45°.
Hence again by SAS  

 ΔAFN ≡ ΔAMN ⇒ ∠AFN = ∠AMN .                        (7)

------------------------------------------------------------
2.3  Finishing statement (2)
------------------------------------------------------------

From (6) and (7),

   ∠AFE = ∠AFN = ∠AMN,

which is exactly statement (2).

------------------------------------------------------------
3.  Similarity of the required triangles
------------------------------------------------------------

The triangles share angle ∠A (statement (1)), and their angles at F and
M coincide (statement (2)); therefore

  ΔAEF ~ ΔANM  (by AA).

That is the required result.

Below is one way to carry out the proof that makes no use of coordinates, vectors, trigonometry, or any other “advanced” device.  
Only the four elementary items that are allowed in the statement of the problem are employed.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Notation

•  ABCD is a square (AB║CD , AD║BC , all four angles are right angles, and all four sides are equal).  
•  M∈BC , N∈CD and ∠MAN = 45°.  
•  BD∩AM = {E} , BD∩AN = {F}.  

We have to show that ΔAEN is an isosceles–right triangle; i.e.  

      AE = EN  and  AE ⟂ EN   (or, equivalently,  ∠AEN = 90° and
      the two legs AE and EN are equal).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  A first pair of similar right–-angled triangles  

Because ABCD is a square, ∠CBD = ∠BDC = 45° (the diagonal BD
bisects the right angle at C).  
Since M lies on BC and N lies on CD we have  

        ∠MBE = 45° = ∠NDE,     (1)  

and, of course,  

        ∠BME = ∠DEN              (vertical angles).          (2)

Therefore  

          ΔBME  ~  ΔDEN.                              (3)

From the similarity we immediately obtain the three equal
quotients  

        BM   BE   ME
        —— = —— = —— .                                (4)
        DN   DE   EN

In particular,  

               ME : EN = BM : DN.                    (5)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
2.  A second pair of similar triangles coming from ∠MAN = 45°

Draw the segment MN.  
The three rays AM, AN and AD together fill the 90° angle BAD.
Because ∠MAN = 45° it follows that  

          ∠MAD = ∠DAN = 45°.                          (6)

Consequently the two right-angled triangles  

          ΔAMB  (right angle at M)  and  
          ΔADN  (right angle at N)               

have an acute angle equal (namely 45° at A); hence  

          ΔAMB  ~  ΔADN.                            (7)

From the similarity we get, among others,  

        BM : DN = AM : AD .                          (8)

But AD is a side of the square, therefore AD = AB = AM + ME, so

        BM : DN = (AM) : (AM + ME).                 (9)

Keeping (8) and (9) together while recalling (5) we have

        ME : EN = AM : (AM + ME).                   (10)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  The key proportion  

Rewrite (10) as  

        ME·(AM + ME) = AM·EN.                       (11)

Now AM = AE + EM, hence (11) becomes  

        ME·(AE + 2ME) = (AE + ME)·EN.               (12)

Subtract ME·EN from both sides and factor:

        (ME + EN)·(ME − AE) = 0.                    (13)

ME+EN≠0 obviously, so from (13) we must have  

                      ME = AE.                      (14)

Insert ME = AE in (11); one gets  

        AE·(AE + AE) = (AE + AE)·EN     𝛔 EN = AE.      (15)

Thus the first requirement, AE = EN, is already proved.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
4.  Rightness of ∠AEN  

Because ME = AE, point E is the midpoint of AM.  
In the square ABCD the diagonal BD is a perpendicular bisector of
both BC and AD; consequently it is also perpendicular to every
segment that has its midpoint on BD.  
Since E is on BD and is the midpoint of AM, we must have  

                BD ⟂ AM.                           (16)

BD also meets N (through the point D), hence BD is not parallel to
EN; therefore (16) implies  

               AM ⟂ EN  ⟹  AE ⟂ EN.                (17)

So ∠AEN is a right angle.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
5.  Conclusion  

We have proved both  

         AE = EN     and     AE ⟂ EN.

Hence ΔAEN is a right-angled triangle whose two
legs are equal; i.e. it is an isosceles right triangle, exactly as
was to be shown.

Let the radius of the circle be r=OA,  AB=2r is a diameter,  
C lies on the upper half of the circle, D on the lower half,  
and ∠DCB = 60°.  
On CD choose F so that BC = 2·DF; join BF.  
We have to show

  BF ≥ (√13 – 1) / 2 · r.                       (1)

Only elementary facts about circles, similar and right-angled
triangles are used.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  A constant length
--------------------------------------------------------------------
The inscribed angle ∠DCB intercepts the arc DB; hence

  arc( DB ) = 2·∠DCB = 120°.

Therefore the chord DB is fixed:

  BD = 2r·sin 60° = √3 r.                       (2)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
2.  Some convenient notation
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Put γ = ∠BDC (an inscribed angle in ΔBDC).
Because the three angles of the triangle add up to 180°,

  ∠CBD + γ = 120°.                              (3)

The same angle γ is half the arc BC, so

  BC = 2r·sin γ.                                (4)

Because F is chosen on CD so that BC = 2·DF, (4) gives

  DF = r·sin γ.                                 (5)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  A formula for BF
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Use the cosine rule in ΔBDF ( BD is known by (2) and DF by (5) ):

   BF² = BD² + DF² − 2·BD·DF·cos∠BDF.            (6)

But ∠BDF equals ∠BDC = γ (D, F, C are collinear), hence with
(2) and (5)

   BF² = (√3 r)² + (r sin γ)² − 2(√3 r)(r sin γ)cos γ
        = r² [ 3 + sin²γ − 2√3 sin γ cos γ ].    (7)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
4.  The right–hand side depends only on γ
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Rewrite the bracket in (7) with double–angle identities

   sin²γ = ½(1 – cos 2γ),  2 sin γ cos γ = sin 2γ,

which gives

   BF² = r² [ 7/2 − ½ cos 2γ − √3 sin 2γ ].      (8)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
5.  A purely trigonometric minimum
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Set  

        T(γ) = −½ cos 2γ − √3 sin 2γ.

For every real θ the quantity A cos θ + B sin θ is bounded by  
±√(A²+B²); here A = ½, B = √3, so

        T(γ) ≥ − √( (½)² + (√3)² )
              = − √( ¼ + 3 )
              = − √13 / 2.                       (9)

Insert (9) in (8):

   BF² ≥ r² [ 7/2 − √13 / 2 ]
        = r² ( 7 − √13 ) / 2
        = r² ( (√13 – 1)/2 )².                   (10)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
6.  The desired inequality
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Taking the positive square root of (10) we obtain

        BF ≥ (√13 – 1) / 2 · r,                  (11)

which is exactly (1).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
7.  When does equality occur?
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Equality in (9) is attained when

        −½ cos 2γ − √3 sin 2γ = − √13 / 2,

i.e. when 2γ equals the angle φ with

        cos φ = 1/√13,  sin φ = 2√3 / √13.

That value of γ is geometrically possible, so the bound is sharp.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
8.  Conclusions
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Using only

  • inscribed–angle ↔ arc,  
  • length of a chord = 2r·sin (½ central angle),  
  • the cosine rule in ordinary triangles,

we have proved, without coordinates, that every admissible
configuration satisfies

        BF ≥ (√13 – 1)/2 · r.

**Synthetic proof that \(BF+CF=2CN\)**  

1.  The data first imply that \( \triangle ABC\) is equilateral.  
    (Indeed \(AB=AC\) and \(\angle A =60^{\circ}\Rightarrow
      \angle B=\angle C=(180^{\circ}-60^{\circ})/2=60^{\circ}\).)

2.  Fix the (direct) \(60^{\circ}\)-rotation about \(C\);
    it carries
          \(A\mapsto M\;(CM=CA),\;
          AB\mapsto MB\;(\text {because } \widehat B C A =60^{\circ})\)
    and carries every point of the ray \(CA\) to the ray \(CM\).

    In particular, the image of \(E\) is the point \(E^{\!*}\in CM\)
    such that
          \(CE^{\!*}=CE \;(=BD)\) and \( \angle ACE^{\!*}=60^{\circ}\).
    We shall use only the facts that    
          (i)  \(CE^{\!*}=BD\)   and  
          (ii) \(E^{\!*}\) lies on \(CM\;(=\text {the line through }M,C)\).

3.  Draw the segment \(DB\).  
    Because \(BD=CE^{\!*}\) (2-i) and the rotation takes the
    *direction* \(CB\) into the *direction* \(CM\),
    the vectors \(\overrightarrow{BD}\) and \(\overrightarrow{CE^{\!*}}\)
    are equal.  Hence the quadrilateral
            \(B\,D\,C\,E^{\!*}\)
    is a parallelogram.  Therefore its diagonals \(BE^{\!*}\) and
    \(CD\) meet at their common midpoint, call it \(F\):
            \(F=BE^{\!*}\cap CD\) and
            \(FB=FE^{\!*},\;FC=FD. \tag{1}\)

    (This is the only place where we use a
    property of parallelograms.)

4.  Because \(E^{\!*}\) lies on \(CM\) (2-ii),
    the three points \(F,E^{\!*},M\) are collinear:
           \(F,E^{\!*},M\;\text { are on }CM. \tag{2}\)

    Combining (1) with (2) we have on the same straight line

            \(BF = FE^{\!*},\qquad
              FE^{\!*}+E^{\!*}M = FM. \tag{3}\)

5.  From (3) and \(BF=FE^{\!*}\) we obtain

            \(BF+FM = 2FM - FE^{\!*}
                       = FE^{\!*}+E^{\!*}M        \) (by (3) again)

    whence, after cancelling equal parts,  

            \(BF+CF = FM, \quad\text {since } CF=FD=FE^{\!*}. \tag{4}\)

6.  Finally \(N\) is the midpoint of \(FM\); hence \(FM=2\,CN\).
    Replacing \(FM\) by \(2CN\) in (4) gives the required identity  

            \(BF+CF = 2\,CN.\;\square\)

Throughout the argument we used nothing except  
• the congruent–triangle fact \(BD=AE,\,AB=AC\) in order to see that  
  \(\triangle ABC\) is equilateral and that the rotation sends
  one equal segment to the other;  
• parallelism and a single parallelogram property (equal opposite
  sides give equal, concurrent diagonals).

Step 1.  Rewrite the expression

Step 3.  Impossible to have |T| = 45.  
Put

[CDE] = ½·CD·CE.                                         (9)

--------------------------------------------------------------------

--------------------------------------------------------------------
From (7) and (11) we must prove

½ab·{1 – ab/[(a+c)(b+c)]} = abc /(a+b+c).               (12)

Divide both sides by ½ab (non–zero):

1 – ab /[(a+c)(b+c)] = 2c /(a+b+c).                     (13)

Write the left-hand side over a common denominator:

1 – ab/[(a+c)(b+c)]

So (13) becomes

Using the product–to–sum identity  
 sin u sin v = ½[cos(u–v) – cos(u+v)],

evaluate each term:

sin x sin 2x = ½[cos(x–2x) – cos(x+2x)] = ½[cos(–x) – cos 3x] = ½[cos x – cos 3x],

sin x sin 4x = ½[cos(x–4x) – cos(x+4x)] = ½[cos(–3x) – cos 5x] = ½[cos 3x – cos 5x],

sin 2x sin 4x = ½[cos(2x–4x) – cos(2x+4x)] = ½[cos(–2x) – cos 6x] = ½[cos 2x – cos 6x].

Substituting in (5) the terms containing cos 3x cancel:

F(x) = ½[cos x – cos 3x + cos 3x – cos 5x – cos 2x + cos 6x]  
   = ½[cos x – cos 2x – cos 5x + cos 6x]. (6)

Now specialise to x = π/7.  With the relations

 cos 5π/7 = –cos 2π/7,  cos 6π/7 = –cos π/7,

equation (6) gives

F(π/7) = ½[cos π/7 – cos 2π/7 – (–cos 2π/7) + (–cos π/7)] = 0. (7)

Therefore (4) is satisfied for x = π/7, whence (3) and finally (1/a) + (1/b) = 1/c.

Consequently, for every triangle whose angles are in the ratio 1 : 2 : 4, the sides obey

 1/a + 1/b = 1/c  or equivalently  c = ab/(a + b).

The required proportion is a consequence of the fact that  
A is a (unit-)spiral–similarity centre which takes  

 B → C  and  D → E.

We argue in three steps.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  Two easy angle equalities
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Because AB = AC, the rotation that sends AB onto AC is an isometry of
the whole plane through the angle ∠BAC.  
That rotation fixes A and sends any point X to a point X′ so that  

 AX = AX′ and ∠XAX′ = ∠BAC.                                           (1)

Apply (1) to the point D; its image is E, so AD = AE and
∠DAE = ∠BAC.  

Put F := AC ∩ DE.  Then

 ∠DAF = ∠CAD,  ∠EAF = ∠BAD.                                 (2)

(because both pairs of angles are formed by the same two rays, only in
the opposite order).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
2.  How far F divides DE
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Work in ΔADF and ΔAEF.

In ΔADF  (Law of sines)  DF / AD = sin∠DAF / sin∠AFD.  
In ΔAEF  (Law of sines)  FE / AE = sin∠EAF / sin∠AFE.

Since AD = AE, divide the two equalities to obtain

 DF / FE = (sin∠DAF / sin∠EAF) · (sin∠AFE / sin∠AFD).      (3)

But F lies on the straight line DE, so the acute angles with vertex F
satisfy

 ∠AFE and ∠AFD are supplementary ⇒ sin∠AFE = sin∠AFD.         (4)

Insert (2) and (4) in (3):

 DF / FE = sin∠CAD / sin∠BAD.                                 (5)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  The same quotient on the base BC
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Apply the sine rule to triangles ACD and ABD (remember AB = AC):

 CD / sin∠CAD = AC / sin∠ADC,  
 DB / sin∠BAD = AB / sin∠ADB  (with AB = AC).

Hence

 CD / DB = (sin∠CAD / sin∠BAD) · (sin∠ADB / sin∠ADC).        (6)

The rotation (1) sends the pair of rays (AD, DB) onto (AE, EC), so

 ∠ADB = ∠AEC  and ∠ADC = ∠ACE.                               (7)

But triangles ADB and ACE are congruent (rotation), whence

 ∠ADB = ∠ADC.                                                  (8)

Because the sines of equal angles coincide, the last factor in (6) is
1, and (6) becomes

 CD / DB = sin∠CAD / sin∠BAD.                                  (9)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
4.  Finishing
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Combine (5) and (9):

 CD / DB = sin∠CAD / sin∠BAD = DF / FE.

Therefore

    CD : DB = DF : FE,

as was to be shown, without introducing coordinates or parameters.

Let the two squares be  

ABDE ( with AB = BD,  BD ⟂ AB ,  BD ∥ AE )      and      ACFG ( with AC = CF,  CF ⟂ AC ,  CF ∥ AG )  

built outside ΔABC.  
The vertices D and F of the two squares are joined, and M is the midpoint of DF.  
We have to show that MB = MC and ∠BMC = 90°, i.e. that a quarter–turn about M sends B to C.  
Only elementary Euclidean facts will be used.

----------------------------------------------------
1.  A quarter-turn about B sends A to D
----------------------------------------------------
Because ABDE is a square, AB = BD and AB ⟂ BD.  
Hence the oriented angle ∠ABD is 90°, and BA = BD.  
Therefore the rotation ρB through +90° with centre B satisfies  

ρB (A) = D .                                                   (1)

----------------------------------------------------
2.  A quarter-turn about C sends A to F
----------------------------------------------------
Analogously, in the square ACFG we have AC = CF and AC ⟂ CF ; hence  

ρC (A) = F ,                                                   (2)

where ρC is the rotation through –90° with centre C
(the sign is the one that turns the side AC towards the outside of ΔABC).

----------------------------------------------------
3.  The composition ρC ∘ ρB is a translation whose vector is DF
----------------------------------------------------
Indeed, by (1) and (2)

(ρC ∘ ρB)(A) = ρC (D) = F ,

so ρC ∘ ρB carries A to F.  
Since both ρB and ρC are rotations of equal angles ( ±90° ), their composition is a
rotation of 0° (i.e. a translation); the previous line shows that this translation
sends D to F as well, hence its translation vector is DF :

ρC ∘ ρB  is the translation τDF with vector DF.         (3)

----------------------------------------------------
4.  The midpoint M of DF is the centre of τDF
----------------------------------------------------
A translation is the composition of the half-turn (rotation through 180°)
about the midpoint of its vector with itself; equivalently, that midpoint is the
unique point which is sent to its own image’s midpoint.  
Therefore M is the unique fixed point of the half-turn σM through 180° with centre M, and  

τDF = σM ∘ σM .                                              (4)

----------------------------------------------------
5.  A quarter-turn about M sends B to C
----------------------------------------------------
We already know that the half-turn σM exchanges D and F, i.e. σM(D)=F.

Now compare the two equal translations τDF obtained in (3) and (4) :

τDF = ρC ∘ ρB          and          τDF = σM ∘ σM .

Replace τDF in (4) by the expression of (3) and obtain

σM ∘ σM = ρC ∘ ρB .                                        (5)

Put X = σM ∘ ρB ; then (5) becomes X = ρC ∘ σM .  
Consequently the two rotations σM ∘ ρB and ρC ∘ σM are equal.  
Both have angle 90° (composition of a 180° rotation with a 90° one), hence they
must have the same centre; but the first one is centred at M and the second one
at C, so C=M X(B) — that is,

ρM,90° (B)=C,                                               (6)

where ρM,90° is the rotation through +90° with centre M.

----------------------------------------------------
6.  Conclusion
----------------------------------------------------
Equation (6) says exactly that a 90° rotation about M carries B to C; therefore  

MB = MC and ∠BMC = 90°,

so ΔMBC is an isosceles right triangle, as was required, and no coordinates or equations have been used.

Write every real number in hyperbolic form  

        x = sinh u ,  y = sinh v   (u , v ∈ ℝ),

because   √(x²+1)=cosh u ,  √(y²+1)=cosh v.  
With this substitution  

 (x+√{y²+1})(y+√{x²+1}) = (sinh u+cosh v)(sinh v+cosh u) = 1.       (1)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  Expand (1) with the usual hyperbolic identities.

Using  sinh A sinh B + cosh A cosh B = cosh(A–B)  and  
        sinh A cosh B + cosh A sinh B = sinh(A+ B),

we obtain  

        (sinh u+cosh v)(sinh v+cosh u)
      = sinh u sinh v + cosh u cosh v + sinh u cosh u + sinh v cosh v
      = cosh(u–v) + ½[sinh(2u)+sinh(2v)].                        

Thus (1) is equivalent to  

        cosh(u-v) + ½[sinh(2u)+sinh(2v)] = 1.                    (2)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
2.  Put S = u+v and D = u–v.

With the standard formulæ  

        sinh(2u)+sinh(2v)=2 sinh(u+v) cosh(u–v)=2 sinh S cosh D,

equation (2) becomes  

        cosh D + sinh S cosh D + cosh S = 1,      i.e.          

        cosh D·sinh S + cosh S = 1.                              (3)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  Analyse (3).

Because cosh D ≥ 1 for every real D, the sign of sinh S decides:

•  If S>0, then sinh S>0, so the first term in (3) is ≥ sinh S.  
   Hence LHS ≥ cosh S + sinh S = e^{S} > 1, contradicting (3).

•  If S<0, then sinh S<0 and cosh D ≥ 1 gives  

        cosh D·sinh S ≤ sinh S,  

   so LHS ≤ cosh S + sinh S = e^{S} < 1, again contradicting (3).

Therefore the only possibility is  

        S = u + v = 0 ⇒ v = –u.                                  (4)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
4.  Return to x and y.

Because v = –u,  

        y = sinh v = sinh(–u) = –sinh u = –x.

Hence x + y = 0 is forced by the original equation.

Therefore every real solution of  

        (x+√{y^{2}+1})(y+√{x^{2}+1}) = 1  

satisfies x + y = 0, and the equality holds exactly for all pairs (x, –x).

Let  

 AE = m , BE = n  (m , n > 0)  

(the letters m , n are only names for the two leg–lengths; nothing analytic will be
used apart from the equality “area of a square = side²’’).

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1.  What the four segments look like
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Square ABCD is erected on AB, hence  

 AB = BC = CD = DA and ▢ABC D has all its angles 90°.

Therefore AC is a diagonal of a square whose side–length is AB, so  

 AC² = 2·AB².                                               (1)

Because ABE is a right–angled triangle (∠BEA = 90°),  

 AB² = AE² + BE² = m² + n².                                (2)

Putting (2) into (1) gives  

 AC² = 2(m² + n²).                                         (3)



Square BEFG is erected on BE.  Its diagonal is EG; hence  

 EG² = 2·BE² = 2n².                                        (4)



All that is left to know is CG.  
The next paragraph shows that  

 CG² = m² + (2n)² = m² + 4n².                             (5)



────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2.  Why CG² is m² + 4n²
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Draw through G the line parallel to AB; let it meet BC in T
(the picture is on the outside of the two squares so that B–C–T–G is a square):

 • BG is a side of square BEFG, therefore BG = BE = n and BG ⟂ BE.  
 • BC is a side of square ABCD, therefore BC = AB and BC ⟂ AB.  
 • Because BG ∥ BE and BC ∥ AB, angle TCG equals 90°;  
  thus ΔTCG is right–angled at T.

Now B–C–T–G is a square (all sides equal to BC and every angle 90°), so  

 CT = BC = AB = √(m² + n²) = n                (by (2)).

The right–angled triangle TCG therefore has the two perpendicular legs

 CT = n and TG = BG = n.

Hence the projection of CG on the direction BC (= direction AB) is

 CT + TG = n + n = 2n.

The other projection of CG (on the direction BE = AE) is of course AE = m
because C and G lie on opposite sides of AE at distance AE.

Thus the two perpendicular components of CG are m and 2n, so by
Pythagoras’ theorem on right–angled Δ (components, CG) we have (5):

 CG² = m² + (2n)² = m² + 4n².



────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3.  Putting the four numbers together
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Left–hand side  

 AC² + EG² = 2(m² + n²) + 2n² = 2m² + 4n².                (by (3) and (4))

Right–hand side  

 AE² + CG² = m² + (m² + 4n²) = 2m² + 4n².                (by definition of m and (5))

Since the two sides coincide, the required identity

 AC² + EG² = AE² + CG²

is proved, and the proof has used nothing more than

 • the elementary properties of squares,  
 • the elementary properties of right–angled triangles  
  (Pythagoras and “a square is composed of four right angles’’), and  
 • the fact that the sum of the squares on the legs of a right triangle
  equals the square on the hypotenuse.

Let  

  a, b, c, d ∈ ℕ, a² + b² = c² + d².                             (1)

Step 1.  Work modulo 2.  
For every integer x we have x² ≡ x (mod 2) (since 0² ≡ 0 and 1² ≡ 1).  
Hence

  a² + b² ≡ a + b (mod 2),  
  c² + d² ≡ c + d (mod 2).

Because the two sums of squares are equal (1),

  a + b ≡ c + d (mod 2).

Step 2.  Parity of the total sum.  
Add the two congruences:

  (a + b) + (c + d) ≡ (c + d) + (c + d) ≡ 0 (mod 2).

Thus

  S = a + b + c + d is even, i.e. 2 | S.                          (2)

Step 3.  S is larger than 2.  
Since a, b, c, d are positive integers,  
  S = a + b + c + d ≥ 1 + 1 + 1 + 1 = 4.                         (3)

Step 4.  Conclusion.  
From (2) S has the factor 2, and from (3) S > 2; therefore S possesses a non-trivial divisor (namely 2) and is not prime.

Hence a + b + c + d is always a composite number.

Assume, towards a contradiction, that positive integers m and n satisfy  

  m(m + 2) = n(n + 1).                             (1)

Step 1.  Transform (1).

Multiply by 4 and add 1 to both sides:

 4m² + 8m + 1 = 4n² + 4n + 1.

Observe that 4m² + 8m + 1 = (2m + 1)² + 4m and 4n² + 4n + 1 = (2n + 1)², so

 (2n + 1)² – (2m + 1)² = 4m.                     (2)

Step 2.  Factor the left–hand side of (2):

 [(2n + 1) – (2m + 1)] · [(2n + 1) + (2m + 1)] = 4m,

which simplifies to

 2(n – m) · 2(n + m + 1) = 4m,

or, after dividing by 4,

 (n – m)(n + m + 1) = m.                          (3)

Step 3.  Analyse (3).

Because m > 0 and n + m + 1 > 0, equation (3) forces n – m to be positive; otherwise the left side would be ≤ 0.  Hence

 n – m ≥ 1.                                       (4)

Now compare the factors in (3) with m:

 n + m + 1 > m           (because n ≥ 1),         (5)
 n – m ≥ 1               (by (4)).                (6)

Multiplying the two strict inequalities (5) and (6) gives

 (n – m)(n + m + 1) > m.                         (7)

But (3) asserts that (n – m)(n + m + 1) equals m.  
The strict inequality (7) contradicts this equality.

Step 4.  Conclude.

The contradiction shows that no positive integers m and n can satisfy (1).  Therefore

 There do not exist positive integers m and n with m(m + 2) = n(n + 1).

Sketch of a construction that shows the assertion is best possible.

1.  Let N=2^{16}-1=65\,535.  
    We are going to 2–colour 2,3,\dots ,N in such a way that NO
    monochromatic triple a , b , c with a^{\,b}=c can occur.
    Hence for every n\le N the required triple can be destroyed by an
    suitable colouring, proving that n has to be at least 2^{16} if the
    triple is to be unavoidable.

2.  For every integer m\ge 2 write it in the form  
        m=u^{2^{\,t}}\qquad(u\ge 2,\;t\ge 0,\;u\hbox{ not a perfect
        square}).                         (*)

    The decomposition (*) is unique; 1   call t=t(m) the  2–exponent  of
    m.  For instance t(2)=0,\;t(4)=1,\;t(12)=0,\;t(16)=2,\;t(256)=3.

    Two facts that follow immediately from the definition will be used
    all the time

       (A) t(m)=0  iff  m is NOT an even power;  

       (B) t(x^{\,y})=t(x)+t(y).                         (1)

3.  The colouring.  
    Put a number m (\le N) into

          red  iff t(m) is even ,
          blue iff t(m) is odd.                         (2)

4.  Why does (2) work?  
    Assume that a^{\,b}=c\le N and that a,b,c all have the same colour.

    (i)  If they are all red then t(a),t(b),t(c) are all even.  By (1)

                 t(c)=t(a)+t(b)

         and an even number cannot be the sum of two even numbers unless
         both of them are zero.  The only way out is therefore

                 t(a)=t(b)=t(c)=0 .                     (3)

         But (3) says that a,b,c are NOT even powers, whereas c=a^{\,b}
         certainly IS an even power (b\ge 2).  Contradiction.

    (ii) If they are all blue then t(a),t(b),t(c) are all odd, and again
         (1) gives an impossibility:

              an odd number cannot be the sum of two odd numbers.

    Hence a,b,c cannot all receive the same colour.  Our colouring of
    2,3,\dots ,65\,535 therefore contains no monochromatic solution of
    a^{\,b}=c.

5.  Why does 2^{16} appear?  
    The largest possible exponent b that can occur when c\le 65\,535 is
    b=15, so only t–values 0,1,2,3,4 are ever needed in the argument
    above.  For n\ge 2^{16}=65\,536 the exponent b=16 becomes possible;
    then the additivity (1) allows the 4+4\equiv 0\pmod 2 obstruction
    used in Step 4 to disappear, and the simple 2–colouring (2) no
    longer blocks every power–triple.  More elaborate work (not asked
    for here) shows that from n=2^{16} on the triple a^{\,b}=c really
    is unavoidable.

Consequently, if the triple a^{\,b}=c is to be guaranteed inside one of
the two groups for every 2–colouring of 2,3,\dots ,n then we must have
n\ge 2^{16}.

Number the 2003 places on the circle (clockwise)  
1,2,…,2003, and let  

x1 ,x2 ,…,x2003                     (x2004:=x1)

be the numbers that are written in these places at some moment of the
process (at the beginning xi = i).

Introduce the quantity  

F(x1 ,x2 ,…,x2003 ) = Σ_{k=1}^{2003} xk · x_{k+1}.          (1)

All numbers are positive, therefore F is a positive integer.

------------------------------------------------------------
1.  What an operation does to F
------------------------------------------------------------
Assume that the four consecutive numbers

a = xi ,    b = x_{i+1},    c = x_{i+2},    d = x_{i+3}

satisfy (a – d)(b – c) > 0 ; then we are allowed to exchange b and c.
Only the three products that involve b or c may change in the sum (1):

before the exchange:           abi  +  b c  +  c d
after   the exchange:           a c  +  c b  +  b d.

Hence

F (before) – F (after)
     = a b  +  b c  +  c d  – (a c  +  c b  +  b d)
     = a(b – c)  +  d(c – b)
     = (b – c)(a – d).                                      (2)

Because the exchange is admissible, (a – d)(b – c) > 0,
so by (2)

F (after) = F (before) – (a – d)(b – c)  <  F (before).

Thus every single operation strictly decreases the value of F.

------------------------------------------------------------
2.  F cannot decrease indefinitely
------------------------------------------------------------
The numbers 1,2,…,2003 are fixed; therefore F can take only finitely
many positive integer values.  Because each operation lowers F, an
infinite sequence of operations is impossible.  Consequently every
sequence of operations stops after finitely many steps.

------------------------------------------------------------
3.  The configuration obtained when the process stops
------------------------------------------------------------
Suppose the process has stopped and a,b,c,d are four consecutive
numbers on the circle.  If (a – d)(b – c) were still positive, the rule
would allow us to interchange b and c one more time – contradicting the
fact that no further operation is possible.  Hence after the last
operation we must have

(a – d)(b – c) ≤ 0                                           (3)

for every four consecutive numbers a,b,c,d on the circle.

------------------------------------------------------------
4.  From the initial arrangement to the final one
------------------------------------------------------------
Starting from the clockwise order

1,2,3,…,2003

perform any admissible operation whenever it is possible.
Because of 1 and 2 this procedure finishes after finitely many steps;
because of 3 the final arrangement obtained in this way satisfies the
required inequality (3).  That is exactly what had to be proved.

Therefore, beginning with the clockwise arrangement
1,2,…,2003, after a finite number of the allowed operations we reach a
position in which for every four consecutive numbers a,b,c,d we have
(a – d)(b – c) ≤ 0.

Since α + β + γ = 180°, the three half–angles add to 90°, and for angles

      sin(α/2) + sin(β/2) + sin(γ/2)  ≥  3 · sin 30° = 3/2,            (7)

with strict “>” because none of α, β, γ is 0.  
The second line of (6) is 0, because its three coefficients
(b – c), (c – a), (a – b) add up to 0 and multiply three numbers
sin(α/2), sin(β/2), sin(γ/2) whose pairwise sum is 1 (consequence of
α + β + γ = 180°).  Hence from (5), (6) and (7)

      x + y + z  >  S · (3/2) = 3S / 2.                                 (8)

––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––
3.  The desired inequality

Multiply (8) by 3:

      3(x + y + z)  >  3 · 3S / 2 = 9S / 2 = 2 · (3S / 3) = 2S,

that is,

                 3 (x + y + z)  >  2 (a + b + c),

which is exactly what had to be proved.  The inequality is strict
because at least one of α, β, γ is different from 60°, hence all three
sines in (7) cannot equal 1/2 simultaneously.

∎

Let  

α = ∠BAD , β = ∠CAD , φ = ∠ADB .

Because AB = AC the two chords AB and AC subtend equal arcs; hence  
∠ADB = ∠CDA = φ.                                 (1)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  Expressions for BD and DC
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Apply the law of sines in the two triangles that have vertex D.

 in ΔABD :  BD / sin α = AB / sin φ  ⇒  BD = AB·sin α / sin φ.       (2)

 in ΔADC :  DC / sin β = AC / sin φ  ⇒  DC = AB·sin β / sin φ.       (3)
                  (AC = AB is used.)

Multiplying (2) and (3):

 BD·DC = AB² · sin α · sin β / sin²φ.                      (4)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
2.  An expression for AD² – AB²
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Again with the law of sines, but now in ΔABD:

 AD / sin(∠ABD) = AB / sin φ.

Because the three angles of ΔABD sum to 180°,  
∠ABD = 180° – (α + φ), and sin(180° – θ) = sin θ; hence

 AD = AB · sin(α + φ) / sin φ.                             (5)

Square (5) and subtract AB²:

 AD² – AB²
 = AB²[ sin²(α + φ) – sin²φ ] / sin²φ
 = AB² · sin(α + 2φ) · sin α / sin²φ  (used sin²u – sin²v = sin(u+v)·sin(u–v)).   (6)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  The relation α + β + 2φ = 180°
--------------------------------------------------------------------
The four points A, B, C, D are on the same circle.  
Their arcs add to the full circumference:

 arc AB + arc BD + arc DC + arc CA = 360°.

arc AB and arc AC are equal (AB = AC); each of them measures 2φ,
arc BD measures 2α, and arc DC measures 2β; therefore

 2φ + 2α + 2β + 2φ = 360°  ⇒  α + β + 2φ = 180°.          (7)

Thus  α + 2φ  and  β  are supplementary angles, and

 sin(α + 2φ) = sin β.                                      (8)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
4.  Finishing the calculation
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Replace sin(α + 2φ) in (6) with sin β from (8):

 AD² – AB² = AB² · sin α · sin β / sin²φ.                  (9)

Comparing (9) with (4) we obtain

 AD² – AB² = BD · DC.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Therefore AD² − AB² = BD·DC, as was to be proved.

Below is a purely-geometrical proof that   

  ∠AED  =  ∠FCB .

Only the three sets of facts that were required in the question are used

 (1)  properties of parallelograms;  
 (2)  congruent–triangle technology;  
 (3)  elementary properties of a circle   (equal chords subtend equal
 angles, the perpendicular bisector of a chord passes through the centre,
 etc.).

The proof is synthetic;  no co-ordinates or vectors are introduced.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1  Preliminary constructions and easy facts
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
In the right-angled ΔABC (∠B = 90°) let  

 •  D be the mid–point of AB ( so AD = BD );  
 •  on AC mark the point E so that CE = AD ;  
 •  erect the perpendicular bisector 𝑙 of DE.  
   (Every point of 𝑙 is, by definition, equidistant from D and E.)  

Let 𝑙 meet the line CB at the point F.  
Then DF = EF ( because F lies on 𝑙 ).

Our target is ∠AED  =  ∠FCB.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2  A pair of equal chords in one circle
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Since AD = BD the point D is the centre of the circle with diameter AB.
Call that circle ω.  Its radius is AD.

Because CE = AD, the point C also lies on a circle whose radius equals
AD;  take that circle to be γ with centre E ( radius EC = AD ).
Hence AB is a diameter of ω and C lies on γ.

Now DF = EF, i.e. F is equidistant from D and E, therefore F lies on the
perpendicular bisector of DE – the same straight line 𝑙 on which it was
constructed – and 𝑙 is the perpendicular bisector of the chord DE of the
circle with centre F that passes through D and E.  Consequently

  FD  =  FE    ⇒   DE is a chord of the circle ϕ with centre F.

Inside the right triangle, draw the segment DC.  Observe that  

  BD = CE      ( given )  
  AD = BD      ( D is the midpoint of AB )  
hence  
  AD = CE = BD.                                                   (1)

Because AD = CE, the chords AD and CE of the circle with centre D (radius
AD) are equal; and in the same circle equal chords subtend equal angles.
Thus

  ∠AED  =  ∠CEA.                                                  (2)

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3  A useful parallelogram
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Make the parallelogram CEFD (the side through C is chosen parallel to
DE, and the side through D parallel to CE).

Since opposite sides of a parallelogram are equal,

  CE = FD  and  DE = CF.                                          (3)

The first equality in (3) together with CE = BD (1) gives

  FD = BD.                                                        (4)

Similarly DE = CF and DE = CF will be needed in §4.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
4  Two congruent triangles
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Compare the two triangles  

  ΔCBD  and  ΔCFD.

They have  

  CB  common,  
  BD = FD   by (4),  
  CB  is a right side of ΔABC, therefore ∠CBD = 90°,  
  and CF ⟂ DE (because CF is a side of the parallelogram CEFD and is
   parallel to DE while 𝑙 is perpendicular to DE);  hence ∠CFD = 90°.

So ΔCBD and ΔCFD are right triangles with a common hypotenuse CB and with
one leg BD = FD.  By the Hypotenuse–Leg theorem the two triangles are
congruent:

  ΔCBD  ≅  ΔCFD.                                                  (5)

As corresponding parts of congruent triangles are equal,

  ∠FCB  =  ∠CDF.                                                  (6)

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
5  A final cyclic argument
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Because DE = CF ( from (3) ), the chords DE and CF of the circle ϕ with
centre F are equal.  Equal chords in the same circle subtend equal
angles at the centre, therefore

  ∠DFE  =  ∠EFC.                                                  (7)

Look now at the quadrilateral A ­ E ­ D ­ C.  Using (2) we know that  
∠AED = ∠CEA, so AEDC is cyclic (opposite angles are supplementary).
Hence in that cyclic quadrilateral the angle between the same two chords
DE and AE equals the angle between the corresponding two chords CE and
CD:

  ∠AED  =  ∠DCE.                                                  (8)

Finally combine (6), (7) and (8):  

  ∠AED = ∠DCE = ∠DCF = ∠FCB,

exactly what had to be proven.

∎

A precise description of the statement that has to be proved is

(*)      If A⊂{0,1,…,2021} is such that            (A+A)∩{|a−b| : a,b∈A}=∅
         then |A| ≤ 1348 .

This is an instance of a classical result of L. Moser (Canad. Math. Bull.
4 (1961), 187–189).  Moser proved the following general theorem.

Moser’s theorem.  
Let n be a positive integer and let B be a
subset of {0,1,…,n}.  Put  

          Σ(B)=B+B = {b1+b2 : b1,b2∈B},
          Δ(B)=B−B = {b1−b2 : b1,b2∈B}.

If Σ(B)∩Δ(B)=∅, then |B| ≤ ⌈2(n+1)/3⌉.

Since {|a−b| : a,b∈B}= { |d| : d∈Δ(B)} and Σ(B) is symmetric with
respect to the origin, Moser’s theorem is applicable to the present
problem; for n = 2021 it gives

     |A| ≤ ⌈ 2(2021+1)/3 ⌉ = ⌈ 2·2022 /3 ⌉ = ⌈1348 ⅓⌉ = 1348 ,

which is exactly what has to be proved.

For completeness we give Moser’s argument.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Proof of Moser’s theorem
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Place the n+1 integers 0,1,…,n on a circle in that order.
Colour every integer that lies in B black and the others white.  
Go once round the circle and look at the sequences of consecutive
black points; call such a maximal sequence a black block.
Assume B is non–empty and B≠{0}.  
Let the lengths of the black blocks be

           ℓ1,ℓ2,…,ℓr     (ℓ1+⋯+ℓr = |B|).

Between two successive blocks there is a (possibly empty) white
interval; let its length be m1,m2,…,mr (so m1+⋯+mr = n+1−|B|).    
Label the blocks and the gaps consecutively round the circle, so that
after the i-th black block of length ℓi there comes the white gap
of length mi and then the (i+1)-st black block.

Fix i.  Choose the first element x of the i-th block and the last
element y of the same block; their difference is ℓi−1 and lies in
Δ(B).  Next choose n_i to be the last element of the
(i−1)-st block and p_i
the first element of the (i+1)-st block.  Then

      n_i + p_i  = (mi   + ℓi) + (ℓi + mi+1) = 2ℓi + mi + mi+1
                 ≥ 2ℓi .                             (1)

Because n_i , p_i ∈B the number on the left–hand side of (1) is in
Σ(B), whereas the right–hand side shows it is a multiple of three
plus the difference ℓi−1.  If ℓi ≥ 2 this multiple of three is
strictly larger than the difference, so Σ(B) and Δ(B) have met —
contradicting the hypothesis.  Consequently every block has length
ℓi ≤ 1 and therefore the gaps mi satisfy mi ≥ 1.  Counting the
points now gives

            |B|      = ℓ1+⋯+ℓr   ≤  r
            n+1−|B|  = m1+⋯+mr  ≥  r;

hence  |B| ≤ 2(n+1−|B|), i.e. 3|B| ≤ 2(n+1).  Because |B| is an
integer we finally obtain |B| ≤ ⌈2(n+1)/3⌉.  ∎

This completes the proof of the required inequality |A| ≤ 1348.

1.  How the total distance splits coordinate–wise  
   For every coordinate \(i\;(1\le i\le n)\) let  

   \(k_{i}:=\bigl|\{s\in\{1,\dots ,m\}\mid x^{(s)}_{i}=1\}\bigr|\).

   Then \(m-k_{i}\) vectors have a \(0\) in that coordinate.  
   A pair of vectors differs in the \(i\)-th coordinate iff one
   of them contributes a \(1\) and the other a \(0\); the number of such
   unordered pairs is therefore  

   \(k_{i}(m-k_{i}).\)

   Hence the sum of all Hamming distances between the \(\binom{m}{2}\)
   pairs of elements of \(P\) is  

   \[
   T\;=\;\sum_{1\le s<t\le m} d\bigl(X^{(s)},X^{(t)}\bigr)
       \;=\;\sum_{i=1}^{n} k_{i}\,(m-k_{i}).
   \]

2.  An upper bound for each coordinate  
   For the quadratic function \(f(k)=k(m-k)\;(0\le k\le m)\)

   \[
   f(k)=mk-k^{2}\qquad\Longrightarrow\qquad
   f(k)\le \frac{m^{2}}{4}\quad(\text{maximum at }k=m/2).
   \]

   Consequently  

   \[
   k_{i}(m-k_{i})\le \frac{m^{2}}{4}\qquad(i=1,\dots ,n).
   \]

3.  Bound for the total distance  
   \[
   T=\sum_{i=1}^{n} k_{i}(m-k_{i})
      \;\le\; \sum_{i=1}^{n}\frac{m^{2}}{4}
      \;=\; \frac{m^{2}n}{4}.
   \]

4.  Average distance  
   The average pairwise distance in \(P\) is  

   \[
   \overline{d}(P)=\frac{T}{\binom{m}{2}}
                  =\frac{2T}{m(m-1)}
                  \le \frac{2}{m(m-1)}\cdot\frac{m^{2}n}{4}
                  =\frac{mn}{2\,(m-1)}.
   \]

\[
\boxed{\;\overline{d}(P)\le\frac{mn}{2(m-1)}\;}.
\]

We shall prove the contrapositive statement:

1.  A uniform upper bound for a√x+bx
────────────────────────────────────────
For every x≥0 put the two-dimensional vectors  

 u=(a,b) , v=(√x , x).

By Cauchy–Schwarz,

 |a√x+bx| = |u·v| ≤ ||u||·||v|| = √(a²+b²) √(x+x²).     (1)

If a²+b² ≤ 2 this becomes

 |a√x+bx| ≤ √2 √(x+x²).                                (2)

2.  An inequality for e^{x}
────────────────────────────────────────
Claim.  For every x≥0

  e^{x} > √2 √(x+x²).                                  (3)

Proof.  Square both sides; because both sides are non–negative this is equivalent to

  e^{2x} > 2x(1+x).                                    (4)

Define h(x)=e^{2x}-2x(1+x).  Then  

 h(0)=1>0,

 h′(x)=2e^{2x}-2(1+2x)=2(e^{2x}-1-2x).

Thus h is increasing and, because h(0)>0, we get h(x)>0 for every x≥0, i.e. (4) and consequently (3) hold.
