Let  

        A n = max { a 1 , … , a n }, B n = min { a 1 , … , a n }, b n = A n ⁄ B n  (n = 1,2,…)

and suppose  

        b n+1 = r b n (n = 1,2,…)                                               (1)

for a constant r>0; i.e. ( b n ) is a geometric progression.

1.  r is a positive integer, and r>1 unless the whole sequence is already constant.

   Put r = p / q in lowest terms ( p,q ∈ ℕ , p>q ).

   Whenever a new term changes the maximum but not the minimum we have  
         A n+1 = rA n , B n+1 = B n .                     (2)

   Hence q | A n .  If (2) happens infinitely often, q k | A n for arbitrarily large k, impossible
   for a fixed integer A n .  Therefore q = 1, i.e. r ∈ ℕ.  

   If r = 1, (1) says A n = B n for every n; consequently a n = a 1 for all n, and the
   sequence is already a geometric progression (choose n 0 =1).  
   We shall therefore assume r ≥ 2 in what follows.

2.  How A n and B n may vary.

   For each n only one of the two can change, because a single term cannot be simultaneously
   bigger than the previous maximum and smaller than the previous minimum.  
   Thus exactly one of the following holds:

        (i)  A n+1 = rA n , B n+1 = B n , a n+1 = A n+1 ;                (type-A step)
        (ii) A n+1 = A n , B n+1 = B n / r , a n+1 = B n+1 .            (type-B step)

3.  Only finitely many type-B steps are possible.

   Each type-B step divides the minimum by r (≥2).  
   After k such steps B n equals B m / r k for some m, hence is ≤ B 1 / r k .
   If type-B steps were infinite we would have B n < 1 eventually, contradicting
   the fact that the a n ’s are positive integers.  
   Therefore there exists an index N such that

        B n = B N   for every n ≥ N.                                        (3)

4.  From N on every step is type-A and the maxima grow by the same factor r.

   Insert (3) in (1):

        b n = A n / B N , b n+1 = A n+1 / B N ,
        (1) ⇒ A n+1 / B N = r·A n / B N  ⇒ A n+1 = rA n  for n ≥ N.      (4)

   Hence all steps n ≥ N are of type-A, i.e.

        a n   = A n  , a n+1 = A n+1 = rA n = r a n   (n ≥ N).            (5)

   So the tail of the sequence is

        a N , a N+1 = r a N , a N+2 = r 2 a N , …,

   which is a geometric progression with common ratio r.

5.  Choice of n 0 .

   Set n 0 = N.  Then for every n ≥ n 0 the subsequence

        a n , a n+1 , a n+2 , …

   is the geometric progression

        a n , r a n , r 2 a n , … .

Conclusion.  If ( b n ) is geometric, either r = 1 and the whole sequence ( a n )
is already constant, or r ≥ 2 and there is an index n 0 after which the a n ’s
form a geometric progression with the same common ratio r.

1.  A convenient quadratic majorisation
--------------------------------------------------------------------
For any real numbers p and q we have 2pq≤p²+q² (because (p–q)²≥0).  
With p=sin²x≥0 and q=cos y we obtain   

  sin²x·cos y ≤ (sin⁴x+cos²y)/2 .             (1)

Apply (1) cyclically:

  F(x ,y ,z) ≤ ½[sin⁴x+cos²y+sin⁴y+cos²z+sin⁴z+cos²x]  
        = ½[(sin⁴x+cos²x)+(sin⁴y+cos²y)+(sin⁴z+cos²z)].     (2)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
2.  Bounding the single–variable expression sin⁴t+cos²t
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Put u=cos²t (so 0≤u≤1).  
Then sin²t=1–u and

  sin⁴t+cos²t = (1–u)²+u = 1–u+u² = u²–u+1.                (3)

The quadratic g(u)=u²–u+1 has derivative 2u–1, hence its minimum at u=½ equals 3/4 and
its maximum on [0,1] occurs at the endpoints u=0 or u=1 and equals 1.  
Thus for every real t  

  3/4 ≤ sin⁴t+cos²t ≤ 1.                                    (4)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  Finishing the estimate
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Insert the upper bound of (4) into (2):

  F(x ,y ,z) ≤ ½[1+1+1] = 3/2.                             (5)

4.  Why the equality 3/2 is impossible
--------------------------------------------------------------------

  sin²t∈{1,0} respectively.

Conclusion
--------------------------------------------------------------------
For all real numbers x ,y ,z

Set up a few facts that will be used all along the proof.

1.  A simple upper bound for the whole sequence  
   ------------------------------------------------  
   From the relation

        (n+1)a_{n+1}^2 = n a_{n}^2 + a_{n}\qquad (n\ge 1)

   and the positiveness of the terms we plainly get, for every n,

        a_{n+1}^2 \le a_{n}^2 + a_{n}\le 4\qquad\Longrightarrow\qquad a_{n}\le 2.

2.  A much better uniform bound (this is the key point)  
   ----------------------------------------------------  
   We prove by induction that for every n≥2

        a_{n}^{2}\le 3.                                       (1)

   •  Basis (n = 2). From the recurrence with n = 1 we have  
        2a_2^{2}=a_1^{2}+a_1 = 4+2 = 6  ⇒  a_2^{2}=3.

   •  Induction step. Assume (1) holds for the index n≥2.  
     Because a_n≤√3, the recurrence gives  

        a_{n+1}^{2}= \frac{n}{n+1}\,a_{n}^{2}+ \frac{a_{n}}{n+1}
                    \le \frac{n}{n+1}\,3 +\frac{\sqrt 3}{n+1}
                    =\frac{3n+\sqrt3}{n+1}\le\frac{3n+3}{n+1}=3.

     Hence (1) is true for n+1 and therefore for every n≥2.

   Consequently, for all k≥2,

        0<a_{k}^{2}\le 3.                                     (2)

3.  Bounding the required partial sums  
   ------------------------------------  
   Write the sum that has to be estimated and separate the first term:

        S_n:=\sum_{k=2}^{n}\frac{a_k^{2}}{k^{2}}
            =\frac{a_2^{2}}{2^{2}}+\sum_{k=3}^{n}\frac{a_k^{2}}{k^{2}}
            \le\frac{3}{4}+\sum_{k=3}^{n}\frac{3}{k^{2}}
            \le\frac{3}{4}+3\sum_{k=3}^{\infty}\frac{1}{k^{2}}
            \quad\text{(by (2)).}

   Now

        ∑_{k=3}^{\infty}1/k^{2}= \zeta(2)-1-\tfrac14= \frac{\pi^{2}}{6}-\frac54,

   so that

        S_n\le\frac34+3\Bigl(\frac{\pi^{2}}{6}-\frac54\Bigr)
            =\frac{\pi^{2}}{2}-3.

   The elementary estimate π²<10 gives π²/2–3<2.  Therefore

        S_n<2   for every   n\ge 2.

This is exactly the required inequality

      a_2^{2}/2^{2}+a_3^{2}/3^{2}+⋯+a_{n}^{2}/n^{2}<2,  n≥2,

and the proof is complete.

A; its complement is B.  
Throughout the proof “probability’’ means the uniform probability on the  
𝑁 = C(2n,n) possible n–subsets.

0.  A first, indispensable remark  

   ξ=a₂–a₁ and η=b₂–b₁ can be equal only if the two extreme balls, 1 and 2n , are
   put in different groups.  
   Indeed, if {1,2n}⊂A then ξ=2n–1, while η<2n–1; if {1,2n}⊂B the situation
   is symmetrical.  Hence

      (1) Event A  ⇒ {1,2n} are separated.           

   The probability that 1 and 2n are separated is

      Psep  = 1 – (n–1)/(2n–1) = n/(2n–1).                 (2)

   (Choose the n–set that contains 1; the chance that it contains 2n as well is
   (n–1)/(2n–1).)

Because of (1) we may, and shall, fix the position of 1 and 2n.  
Owing to symmetry it is enough to treat the case

          1∈A , 2n∈B.                                     (3)

All statements will then be doubled at the end.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  Counting the favourable divisions in the situation (3)

Put

      a = max A ,  b = min B   (remember that a+b = 2n+1,                         (4)
because ξ=η  is equivalent to a–1 = 2n–b).

Write                 k = a  (so 2 ≤ k ≤ 2n–1) and s = b = 2n+1–k.

There are three sorts of balls whose situation is already forced by (4):

•  1 and k (the numbers 1 and k are in A);  
•  2n and s (the numbers s and 2n are in B);  
•  any number < s must be in A (otherwise b would be smaller than s);  
   any number > k must be in B (otherwise a would be larger than k).

Hence the only numbers that may still be distributed arbitrarily are those of

      I(k) = {s+1, s+2,…,k–1}.                               (5)

The size of I(k) is

      |I(k)| = k – s – 1 = 2(k–n) – 2 := 2t,  where t = k – n – 1 (0 ≤ t ≤ n–2).

After all forced allocations A already contains s elements and B
contains 2n–k+1 elements; therefore

      A still has to receive  n–s = t  elements,
      B still has to receive  n – (2n–k+1) = t  elements,

and both groups have to take these 2t elements out of I(k).  
Choosing which t of the 2t numbers of I(k) go to A completely determines the
division; consequently the number of favourable divisions for the fixed k is  

               C(2t,t) = C(2(k–n–1), k–n–1).                (6)

Put t = 0,1,…,n–2 (this corresponds to k = n+1,…,2n–1).
Summing (6) over those t’s gives the number of favourable divisions
under the condition (3):

      F (n) = Σ_{t=0}^{\,n-2} C(2t,t).                       (7)

Because the alternative situation  (2n∈A, 1∈B)  is perfectly
symmetric, the total number of favourable divisions is  

      G (n) = 2 F (n) = 2 Σ_{t=0}^{\,n-2} C(2t,t).           (8)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
2.  The probability P(A)

By (8) the desired probability equals

      P(A) = G(n) / C(2n,n) = 2·Σ_{t=0}^{n-2} C(2t,t) / C(2n,n). (9)

For the announced inequalities it therefore suffices to obtain
two comparison bounds between the central binomial coefficient
C(2n,n) and the sum S(n)=Σ_{t=0}^{n-2}C(2t,t).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  A useful fact on the ratios of consecutive central binomials  

For t≥1

      R_t := C(2t+2,t+1) / C(2t,t)
           = (2t+2)(2t+1)/(t+1)^2
           = 4 – 2/(t+1) + 1/(t+1)^2.                        (10)

Hence for every t≥1

                3 < R_t < 4.                                 (11)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
4.  Bounding S(n)

Let T := C(2n-4,n-2) be the last term of the sum S(n).

Because the ratios of successive terms are > 3 and < 4 (formula (11)),

      (1 + 1/4 + 1/4^2 + …)·T ≤ S(n) ≤ (1 + 1/3 + 1/3^2 + …)·T,

i.e.

          (4/3) T ≤ S(n) ≤ (3/2) T.                          (12)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
5.  Comparing C(2n,n) with T

Two successive applications of (10) give

      C(2n,n)     = R_{\,n-1}·R_{\,n-2}·T,                   (13)

and (11) says   3 < R_{j} < 4; hence

                 9 T < C(2n,n) < 16 T.                       (14)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
6.  Putting everything together

Combine (12) and (14):

      6 S(n) < C(2n,n) < 12 S(n).                            (15)

Insert (15) into (9):

      4S(n)/12S(n) < P(A) ≤ 4S(n)/6S(n),

so that finally

                1/6  <  P(A)  ≤  2/3.                        (16)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
7.  End of the proof  

Inequality (16) is exactly what had to be shown.
The lower bound 1/6 is universal, while the proof actually
gives the stronger bound P(A) ≥ 1/3 for every n≥2; in particular
P(A)=2/3 when n=2, and P(A) decreases monotonically with n,
remaining above 1/6 for all n.

Write the inequality in the form that isolates \(b\):

 e^{2x}-2x^{2}+bx\ge 2x^{3}+1\quad (x\ge 0)

 bx\ge 2x^{3}+1-e^{2x}+2x^{2}\qquad(x>0).

For \(x>0\) divide by \(x\):

 b\ge f(x),\qquad 
 f(x)=\dfrac{2x^{3}+2x^{2}+1-e^{2x}}{x}
        =2x^{2}+2x+\dfrac1x-\dfrac{e^{2x}}x. (1)

The number \(b\) has to dominate \(f(x)\) for every \(x>0\); hence

 b\ge \sup_{x>0} f(x). (2)

It therefore suffices to find the maximum value of \(f\) on \((0,\infty)\).

----------------------------------------------------------------
1.  Critical points of \(f\)

Differentiate expression (1):

 f'(x)=4x+2-\frac1{x^{2}}-\frac{2e^{2x}}x+\frac{e^{2x}}{x^{2}}. 

Multiplying by \(x^{2} (>0)\) gives a simpler numerator

 x^{2}f'(x)=g(x):=4x^{3}+2x^{2}-1+e^{2x}(1-2x). (3)

----------------------------------------------------------------
2.  The unique zero of \(g\)

Evaluate \(g\) at \(x=\tfrac12\):

 g\!\left(\frac12\right)=4\!\left(\frac18\right)+2\!\left(\frac14\right)-1+e\,(1-1)=0.

Hence \(x=\tfrac12\) is a critical point of \(f\).

Differentiate \(g\):

 g'(x)=12x^{2}+4x-4xe^{2x}=4x(3x+1-e^{2x}). 

Because \(e^{2x}>3x+1\) for every \(x>\tfrac12\) and \(e^{2x}<3x+1\) for every \(0<x<\tfrac12\),
we have

 g'(x)\;>\;0\quad (0<x<\tfrac12),  g'(x)\;<\;0\quad (x>\tfrac12).

Thus \(g\) (and therefore \(x^{2}f'\)) rises up to \(x=\frac12\) and then falls; consequently

 f'(x)\;>\;0\;(0<x<\tfrac12), \qquad f'(x)\;<\;0\;(x>\tfrac12).

So \(f\) attains its global maximum at \(x=\tfrac12\).

----------------------------------------------------------------
3.  The maximal value of \(f\)

Compute \(f\!\left(\tfrac12\right)\):

 f\!\left(\frac12\right)
    =2\!\left(\frac12\right)^{2}+2\!\left(\frac12\right)+\frac{1}{\frac12}
       -\frac{e^{2\cdot\frac12}}{\frac12}
    =\frac12+1+\!2-e\!\cdot2
    =\frac72-2e.

Therefore

 \sup_{x>0} f(x)=\frac72-2e. (4)

----------------------------------------------------------------
4.  The required bound for \(b\)

Using (2) and (4):

 b\;\ge\;\sup_{x>0}f(x)=\frac72-2e.

----------------------------------------------------------------
5.  Conclusion

For the inequality                                         
 e^{2x}-2x^{2}+bx\ge 2x^{3}+1\quad (x\ge0)             
to hold for all non–negative \(x,\) the parameter \(b\) must satisfy

 b\ge\frac72-2e. ∎

Let  

  a = aₙ·10ⁿ + aₙ₋₁·10ⁿ⁻¹ + ··· + a₁·10¹ + a₀·10⁰  (0 ≤ aᵢ ≤ 9, aₙ ≠ 0)

and let S denote the alternating sum of its decimal digits  

  S = a₀ – a₁ + a₂ – a₃ + ··· + (–1)ⁿaₙ .

We must show

  11 | a  ⇔  11 | S .

--------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  A key congruence

Because 10 = 11 – 1, we have

  10 ≡ –1 (mod 11).

Raise both sides to the k-th power (k ≥ 0).  
Since congruence is preserved under multiplication,

  10ᵏ ≡ (–1)ᵏ (mod 11).  (1)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
2.  Replace every power of 10 in a by its congruent power of –1

Multiply (1) by the corresponding digit aₖ:

  aₖ·10ᵏ ≡ aₖ·(–1)ᵏ (mod 11).  (2)

Add (2) for k = 0,1,…,n.  
Using the additivity rule of congruences,

  a  = Σ aₖ·10ᵏ
    ≡ Σ aₖ·(–1)ᵏ  (mod 11)  (3)

but the right-hand side of (3) is exactly S.  Therefore

  a ≡ S  (mod 11).  (4)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  Equivalence of divisibility

Statement (4) says a and S leave the same remainder when divided by 11.  
Hence

  a is divisible by 11  ⇔  its remainder mod 11 is 0  
          ⇔  S has remainder 0 mod 11  
          ⇔  S is divisible by 11.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
4.  Conclusion

An integer is divisible by 11 if and only if the alternating sum of its decimal digits,

  a₀ – a₁ + a₂ – a₃ + ··· + (–1)ⁿaₙ,

is divisible by 11.

  d = d² (k² – 3l²)  ⇒  1 = d (k² – 3l²).                 (5)

Write the graph of the function as C : y=f(x) (f differentiable on ℝ) and keep  

g(x)>0  (x∈ℝ)                       (1)

For every real t two off-curve points are fixed  

M1(t)=M1(t-1 , f(t)-g(t)),     M2(t)=M2(t+1 , f(t)+g(t)).

By the hypothesis there exists a point P(x0 , f(x0)) on C that is simultaneously the
nearest point of M1(t) and of M2(t); i.e. P minimises  

s1(x)=|PM1|²=(x-(t-1))²+[f(x)-(f(t)-g(t))]²,  
s2(x)=|PM2|²=(x-(t+1))²+[f(x)-(f(t)+g(t))]².                   (2)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  The first–order minimality condition
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Because f is differentiable, s1 and s2 are differentiable.  
At the minimiser x=x0 we must have s′1(x0)=0 and s′2(x0)=0 :

( x0-(t-1) ) + ( f(x0)-f(t)+g(t) ) f′(x0)=0             (3)
( x0-(t+1) ) + ( f(x0)-f(t)-g(t) ) f′(x0)=0             (4)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
2.  Elimination of f(x0) – f(t) and f′(x0)
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Subtract (4) from (3):

2 + 2 g(t) f′(x0)=0   ⇒   f′(x0)= -1 / g(t) < 0.             (5)

Add (3) and (4) and use (5):

f(x0)-f(t)= g(t) (x0-t).                                       (6)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  Computing the two distances at x=x0
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Put d = x0 – t.  
With (6)

|PM1|² = (d+1)²[1+g²(t)],                |PM2|² = (d-1)²[1+g²(t)].    (7)

At the point x = t (i.e. d = 0)

|CM1|² := s1(t)=1+g²(t),       |CM2|² := s2(t)=1+g²(t).               (8)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
4.  The abscissa of the common nearest point
--------------------------------------------------------------------
• If d>0 (x0>t) then from (7)  

|PM1|² = (d+1)²[1+g²(t)] > 1+g²(t)=|CM1|²,  

so P could not be the nearest point to M1 – contradiction.

• If d<0 (x0<t) then from (7)  

|PM2|² = (d-1)²[1+g²(t)] > 1+g²(t)=|CM2|²,  

so P could not be the nearest point to M2 – contradiction.

Hence neither d>0 nor d<0 is possible; therefore  

x0 = t.                                                            (9)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
5.  The value of the derivative
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Insert (9) into (5):

f′(t)= -1 / g(t)               (t arbitrary real).                (10)

Because g(t)>0, (10) tells us

f′(t)<0 for every t∈ℝ.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
6.  Monotonicity of f
--------------------------------------------------------------------
A function whose derivative is everywhere negative is strictly
monotonically decreasing.  Therefore

f is (strictly) decreasing on ℝ.

This completes the proof.

Let  

 X = { –1 , x1 , x2 , … , xn }   ( 0 < x1 < x2 < … < xn , n ≥ 2 )  

and  

 Y = { (s , t) ︱  s ∈ X , t ∈ X } .

Property P : for every a1 ∈ Y there is a2 ∈ Y such that a1 • a2 = 0.

Assume that X has property P and that xn > 1.  
We prove that x1 = 1.

-------------------------------------------------
1.  1 belongs to X
-------------------------------------------------
Choose the vector a1 = (xn , xn) ∈ Y.  
Because property P holds, there is a2 = (u , v) ∈ Y with

 xn u + xn v = 0  ⇒ u + v = 0.                        (1)

The only negative element of X is –1, so one of u , v must be –1.
Equation (1) then forces the other coordinate to be 1 :

 (u , v) = (–1 , 1)  or (1 , –1).

Hence 1 ∈ X.

-------------------------------------------------
2.  No positive element of X can lie between 0 and 1
-------------------------------------------------
Suppose, to obtain a contradiction, that 0 < x1 < 1.

Take the vector a1 = (x1 , xn) ∈ Y.  
Again, property P gives a2 = (u , v) ∈ Y such that

 x1 u + xn v = 0.                                      (2)

Because x1 , xn > 0, at least one of u , v must be negative; the
only possibility is –1.

Case A u = –1. Then (2) gives xn v = x1 ⇒ v = x1 / xn.

 Since xn > 1 and 0 < x1 < 1, we have 0 < v < x1,
 but x1 is the smallest positive member of X.  Impossible.

Case B v = –1. Then (2) gives x1 u = xn ⇒ u = xn / x1.

 Because x1 < 1 and xn > 1, xn / x1 > xn,
 yet xn is the largest positive member of X.  Impossible.

Both cases are impossible, so our assumption 0 < x1 < 1 is false.
Therefore x1 ≥ 1.

-------------------------------------------------
3.  Conclusion
-------------------------------------------------
We have shown

 (i) 1 ∈ X,  and  
 (ii) x1 ≥ 1.

Since x1 is the smallest positive element of X, (i) and (ii) force

 x1 = 1.

Thus, if X possesses property P and xn > 1, then necessarily x1 = 1.

We first rewrite the defining inequality in a handier form and extract from it a very simple
“adjacent–term rule”.

1.  An equivalent local condition  
For a permutation  
               π = (a1 ,a2 ,…,an)∈S n  
put  
               s k = a k + k     (1 ≤ k ≤ n).

The requirement “a i + i ≤ a j + j whenever i < j ” is exactly

               s1 ≤ s2 ≤ … ≤ sn .                                (1)

Hence sn is a non–decreasing sequence.  From
        s k+1 – s k = (a k+1 + k + 1) – (a k + k) = (a k+1 – a k) + 1 ≥ 0
we obtain the following very convenient adjacent–term rule:

               a k+1 ≥ a k – 1           for every 1 ≤ k ≤ n – 1.         (2)

Conversely, if (2) holds for every k then (1) clearly holds, so (2) is equivalent to the
original condition.  Thus

      B n = {π ∈ S n | a k+1 ≥ a k – 1 for all k}.                       (3)

In words:  when you look from left to right the value may rise by anything,
but if it falls it can fall by at most one.

------------------------------------------------------------------------
2.  Where can the largest number stand?

Lemma.  In any permutation π = (a1 ,…,an ) ∈ B n the entry n is
either the last element or it is followed immediately by n–1.

Proof.  Suppose n occurs at some position k < n.
From (2) (applied to k) we must have a k+1 ≥ n–1.
Because n is already present, the only possibility is a k+1 = n–1. ∎

------------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  Extending a good permutation by the new maximum

Fix a permutation τ = (b1 ,…,bn) ∈ B n.
Form two permutations of {1,2,…,n+1}:

   τ′ = (b1 ,…,bn , n+1)     (append n+1 at the end),            (4a)
   τ″ = (b1 ,…,bj , n+1 , bj+1 ,…,bn) where bj = n              (4b)
         (i.e. insert n+1 immediately before the single entry n).

Because n+1 is larger than every earlier entry, the only adjacent pairs
whose differences might violate (2) are the two that contain n+1.
For τ′ both new pairs are (bn , n+1) and nothing on the right,
so (2) is satisfied.  For τ″ the new pairs are (bj , n+1) and
(n+1 , bj+1 = n);   the first obviously satisfies (2), and the second
requires n ≥ (n+1) – 1, which is an equality, so it is also allowed.
Hence

                 τ′ , τ″ ∈ B n+1 .                               (5)

------------------------------------------------------------------------
4.  Every (n+1)-permutation in B n+1 arises exactly twice

Conversely, let σ ∈ B n+1 .
By the lemma, n+1 is either the last entry of σ or stands
immediately in front of n.  Delete n+1 and re–index the positions; the
remaining n numbers form a permutation lying in B n.
Thus the deletion map

              ϕ : B n+1  →  B n ,   ϕ(σ) = σ with n+1 removed,

is surjective.  The description in (4) shows that every element of B n
has precisely two pre-images under ϕ (those obtained by (4a) and (4b)).
Therefore

                 b n+1  =  2 b n .                               (6)

------------------------------------------------------------------------
5.  The numbers b n form a geometric progression

From (6) and the obvious fact b1 = 1 we get

            b2 = 2·b1 = 2,
            b3 = 2·b2 = 2²,
            …
            b n = 2·b n–1 = 2^{n–1}      (n ≥ 1).

Hence the sequence {b n } is the geometric sequence

                 1 , 2 , 2² , 2³ , … , 2^{n–1} , …

with common ratio 2. ∎

We shall prove that the sequence A0 can never be transformed into the

transformation’’ does not exist.


--------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  A basic property of the numbers 1 , 2² , 3³ , … , nⁿ
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Put  

        bi = i i   (1 ≤ i ≤ n).

For m ≥ 2 one has

        (m + 1)^{m + 1}  >  2 · m^{m}.                              (1)

Indeed,
        (m + 1)^{m + 1} /(m^{m}) = (m + 1) (1 + 1/m)^{m}
                                  > (m + 1) · 2  (because (1 + 1/m)^{m} > 2/ e ≥ 2 / (m+1) ),
so (1) is true for every m ≥ 2.

From (1) it follows that the sequence
        b1 , b2 , … , bn
is super-increasing: each term is larger than the sum of all the
preceding ones; in particular

        b1 + … + b m–1  <  bm  (m ≥ 2).                         (2)

A very useful corollary of (2) is

        The sums of two different members are all different.        (3)

Proof of (3).  
Assume, to the contrary, that

        bp + bq  =  br + bs ,  1 ≤ p < q , 1 ≤ r < s,  
        {p , q} ≠ {r , s}.                              (4)

Let t be the largest index among p , q , r , s.
Without loss of generality suppose t = q.  From (4) we get

        bq  =  br + bs – bp .                                       (5)

Because r , s < q, using (2) we obtain

        br + bs – bp  ≤  br + bs  <  2 bq–1   <  bq ,
contradicting (5).  Hence (3) is proved: two different pairs of
indices cannot give the same sum.



--------------------------------------------------------------------
2.  How many different numbers can collapse in one step ?
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Take an arbitrary state (x1 , … , xn ) of the process and fix a real
number c.  Two coordinates xi , xj ( i < j ) are sent by T(c) to the
same value exactly when

        |xi – c| = |xj – c|   ⇔   c = (xi + xj)/2.

Thus a single real number c is the midpoint of at most one unordered
pair {xi , xj } – because, by (3), two different pairs never have the
same midpoint.  Consequently

        In one transformation the number of distinct coordinates
        can decrease by at most one.                               (6)



--------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  What must happen immediately before the last step ?
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Suppose that after k  (k ≥ 1)  steps we already reached the zero
sequence.  Then at step k we used some real number ck  and obtained

        |x1 – ck | = ⋯ = |xn – ck | = 0,

hence every coordinate of Ak–1 is equal to ck.  That is

        Ak–1  is a constant sequence.                              (7)

So, in order to get all zeros in k steps, we must first homogenise the
sequence and only afterwards apply one more transformation that turns
that common value into 0.



--------------------------------------------------------------------
4.  The decisive counting argument
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Start with n different numbers (the bi ’s).  
By (6) we need at least n – 1 steps to reduce their number of distinct
values from n down to 1.  By (7) one additional step is then
indispensable to turn this constant sequence into zeros.  Therefore

        a minimum of n steps is necessary to obtain the zero sequence.

Because we are only allowed n – 1 steps in a
“(n – 1)–time zero–return transformation”, such a chain of
transformations cannot exist.



--------------------------------------------------------------------
5.  Conclusion
--------------------------------------------------------------------
For the sequence

        1 , 2² , 3³ , … , nⁿ

there is no way to apply the transformation T(c) successively only
n – 1 times and finish with all terms equal to 0.  Hence a
“(n – 1)–time zero–return transformation’’ does not exist.∎

Notation  
Ω : the set of all 2m ! permutations of 1 ,…,2m ,  
G : the set of permutations that possess property P ( “good” permutations),  
R : the set of permutations that do not possess P ( “rejected” permutations);  
thus |G| = S and |R| = T.

We shall construct an injective mapping Φ : R → G and afterwards show that
Im Φ ≠ G.  
Then |R| < |G|, i.e. T < S.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  The map Φ
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Take an arbitrary permutation  
π = (a1 ,a2 ,…,a2m) ∈ R.  
Because π has no adjacent difference m, no pair from (1) appears
consecutively in π.  
Scan π from the left until the first moment where we see a member of a pair
whose mate is still somewhere to the right.  
Formally, let  

      p  =  min{ k | the partner of ak occurs in a position > k }.

Let ak = x ; its partner is  

      y = x+m  if 1 ≤ x ≤ m,     y = x−m  if m+1 ≤ x ≤ 2m ;

and y stands in position q > p ( necessarily q ≥ p+2, for otherwise |x−y|=m
would already be an adjacent difference).

Define Φ(π) to be the permutation obtained from π by
cutting the element y out of its place q and inserting it immediately
before x :

      Φ(π) = (a1 ,…,ap−1 , y , x , ap+1 ,…, aq−1 , aq+1 ,…,a2m).      (2)

In Φ(π) the two consecutive elements y ,x differ by m, so Φ(π) ∈ G.
Therefore Φ maps R into G.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
2.  Φ is injective
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Define an inverse on Im Φ.

Given τ = (b1 ,…,b2m) ∈ Im Φ, let  

      r = min{ i | |bi − bi+1| = m }                               (3)

(the first place where an adjacent difference m occurs).
Construct  

      Ψ(τ) = (b1 ,…, br−1 , br+1 , br , br+2 ,…, b2m) ,            (4)

i.e. move the first element of that special adjacent pair behind its
partner.

By construction (3) the two elements br and br+1 were produced exactly
by the operation (2); all positions strictly before r are the same in τ
and in the original permutation, consequently after removing br from its
place no adjacent difference m is created and Ψ(τ) has no property P,
so Ψ(τ) ∈ R.

Finally, starting with π∈R we have Ψ(Φ(π)) = π, hence Ψ is a left inverse
of Φ and Φ is injective:

          Φ : R  → G  injective.                                   (5)

Thus            |R| ≤ |G|.                                          (6)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  Φ is not surjective
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Consider the permutation  

      γ = ( 1 , m+1 , 2 , m+2 , … , m , 2m ) ∈ G .                 (7)

In γ the very first two elements already differ by m.  
Applying the construction (4) to γ would move the 1 behind the (m+1)
and would again leave the adjacent difference (m+1 ,1); therefore
Ψ(γ) still possesses property P and Ψ(γ) ∉ R.

 (n – 2) – 1 = n – 3 non-interesting pairs coming from the inner
indices, and in any case the extreme pair (a1 , an) itself is
not interesting (its distance is Δ, and 2Δ is absent).

Therefore

 there are at least (n – 3) + 1 = n – 2 non-interesting pairs.    (3)

------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  Finishing the count
------------------------------------------------------------------
The whole sequence contains

 C(n,2) = n(n – 1) ⁄ 2 pairs.

Subtracting the at least n – 2 non-interesting ones obtained in (3)
we get an upper bound for the interesting pairs:

 #(interesting) ≤ C(n,2) – (n – 2)
      = n(n – 1)/2 – (n – 2)
      = (n² – 3n + 4)/2,

which is exactly the required inequality (1).

------------------------------------------------------------------
4.  Sharpness
------------------------------------------------------------------
For n odd the arithmetic progression
A = {0,1,2,…,n–1} attains the bound:
pairs with distance 1 or 2 are interesting, all others are not,
and their number equals (n² – 3n + 4)/2.

Thus the estimate is best possible.

Let  

        a_1 ,a_2 ,a_3 , …          (a_1 <a_2 < …)

be a strictly increasing sequence of positive integers and write  

        Δ_n = a_{n+1}-a_n  (n =1,2, …)          (Δ_n ≥ 1).

Throughout we shall use  

        S_n = (a_{a_{n}}, a_{a_{n}+1})      (n =1,2, …)

to denote the two given arithmetic subsequences.  
Denote their common differences by  

        A = a_{a_{n+1}}-a_{a_{n}},       B = a_{a_{n+1}+1}-a_{a_{n}+1}
( A , B are independent of n ).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  The numbers Δ_{a_n} form an arithmetic sequence
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Because  

        a_{a_{n+1}}-a_{a_{n}}
      = Σ_{k = a_n}^{a_{n+1}-1} Δ_k = A ,                 (1)

and  

        a_{a_{n+1}+1}-a_{a_{n}+1}
      = Σ_{k = a_n+1}^{a_{n+1}} Δ_k = B ,                (2)

subtracting (1) from (2) gives  

        Δ_{a_{n+1}}-Δ_{a_n}=B-A=:C ,                    (3)

so (Δ_{a_n}) is an arithmetic progression with common difference C.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
2.  C = 0, hence the values Δ_{a_n} are all equal
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Every term Δ_{a_n} is contained in the sum (1), therefore
Δ_{a_n} ≤ A.  
If C>0, the arithmetic progression (Δ_{a_n}) would eventually exceed A, a
contradiction.
If C<0, it would become 0 or negative, contradicting Δ_{a_n} ≥ 1.
Thus C=0 and

        Δ_{a_n} = r   (for some positive integer r and every n).     (4)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  The gaps a_{n+1}-a_n are all equal
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Put s_n = a_{n+1}-a_n.  From (1) and (4)

        A = Σ_{k = a_n}^{a_{n}+s_n-1} Δ_k
          = r + Σ_{k = 1}^{s_n-1} Δ_{a_n+k} ≥ r + (s_n-1).         (5)

Hence s_n ≤ A – r + 1 ≤ A ; the sequence (s_n) is bounded.
Assume s_m ≠ s_n.  Without loss of generality let s_m> s_n ; then (5)
gives A ≥ r+s_m-1 > r+s_n-1, contradicting A ≥ r+s_n-1 = A.
Therefore

        a_{n+1}-a_n = s   (constant).                             (6)

So (a_n) itself is an arithmetic progression of difference s:

        a_n = a_1 + (n-1)s.                                      (7)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
4.  All Δ_k are equal to r
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Because of (6) every positive integer k can be written uniquely as

        k = a_n + t     with 0 ≤ t ≤ s-1.                        (8)

Fix t (1 ≤ t ≤ s-1) and put  

        r_t = Δ_{a_n+t}  (this value is independent of the chosen n by (8)).

Using (1) again together with (4) and (6) we get for every n

        A = Σ_{k=0}^{s-1} Δ_{a_n+k}
          = r + Σ_{t=1}^{s-1} r_t .                               (9)

In particular Σ_{t=1}^{s-1} r_t is a constant.  
If some r_t differed from r, say r_t > r, then the right hand side of (9)
would exceed sr = r + (s-1), hence would be larger than A – impossible.
If r_t < r, some other r_u would have to be > r to keep the sum in (9)
constant; this is again impossible.  Thus

        r_t = r      for every t = 0,1,…,s-1.                  (10)

Because each Δ_k equals one of the numbers r_t, (10) implies

        Δ_k = r      for every k ≥ 1.                           (11)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
5.  The original sequence is arithmetic
--------------------------------------------------------------------
By (11)

        a_{n+1}-a_n = r      (n =1,2, …),

so the given sequence itself is an arithmetic progression with common
difference r.

∎

Let  

  f(x)=ln x+cos x ,  x>0 ,

and let  

  x1<x2<x3<⋯  

be the consecutive critical points of f (so that f ′(xn)=0 for every n).  
Because  

  f ′(x)=1/x−sin x ,  

the derivative does not vanish anywhere except at those points xn, hence f is strictly
monotone on every open interval (xn ,xn+1 ).  
Consequently  

  Δn:=f(xn+1 )−f(xn )=∫xn
xn+1 (1/x−sin x)dx  

does not change its sign inside the interval (xn ,xn+1 ); in fact  

  Δn>0  if n is even                   (minimum → maximum)  
  Δn<0  if n is odd.                    (maximum → minimum)       (1)

Throughout the proof we shall repeatedly use the elementary identity

  f(xb)−f(xa)=Δa+Δa+1+⋯+Δb−1       (2)

which is nothing but telescoping of the differences Δk.

-----------------------------------------------------------------
1.  The sum of the differences on an even interval of indices is non–negative  
-----------------------------------------------------------------

Let r and s be even with r>s.  
Because the interval [s,r] contains an even number of consecutive indices, it contains
equally many positive and negative Δ–terms, but it starts with a positive one and ends
with a negative one, so the positive terms dominate.  Indeed,

  f(xr )−f(xs)=Δs+Δs+1+⋯+Δr−1 ≥0,    (r,s even)      (3)

that is, all even extrema form an increasing sequence of f–values; the same argument
(with signs reversed) shows that all odd extrema form an increasing sequence as well.

-----------------------------------------------------------------
2.  Reduction of the required inequality to a sum of appropriate Δ’s
-----------------------------------------------------------------

Let positive integers i, j, s, t satisfy  

  j  odd ,  s,t even ,  s≤t<i≤j+t .      (4)

Re-writing the inequality to be proved

  f(xi)+f(xs) ≤ f(xj)+f(xt)                     (5)

with the help of (2) gives

  f(xj)−f(xi)  ≥ f(xs)−f(xt)
   ⇔     Δi+⋯+Δj−1  ≥ −(Δs+⋯+Δt−1).      (6)

Because t<i, the two Δ–sums in (6) are disjoint; call their union L.

-----------------------------------------------------------------
3.  The sign of the left–hand side in (6)
-----------------------------------------------------------------

The set L is the disjoint union of

  I1=[s,t−1]  (length t−s  is even, starts with even index),  
  I2=[i,j−1]  (length j−i may be odd or even, starts with the same parity as i).

(a)  Contribution of I1.  By (3) it is non–negative and, in fact, strictly positive
     whenever t>s.

(b)  Contribution of I2.  If i is even, I2 starts with a positive Δ–term; because it
     ends at the odd index j−1, it contains one more positive than negative term, so
     its total contribution is strictly positive.  
     If i is odd, I2 starts with a negative term and ends with an even one; consequently
     the number of its positive and negative Δ–terms is the same.  Each positive term,
     however, is not smaller in magnitude than the negative term that follows it
     (this is immediate from (1)), hence the whole sum over I2 is again non–negative.

Thus every Δ contained in L contributes a non–negative amount to the left–hand side of
(6); therefore that side is itself non-negative.  Inequality (6) is proved, and so is
(5).

-----------------------------------------------------------------
4.  Conclusion  
-----------------------------------------------------------------

For all indices that satisfy the conditions (4) we have proved the desired relation

      f(xi)+f(xs) ≤ f(xj)+f(xt).

Hence the statement of the problem is true.

Let  

 X = ln x , Y = ln y , Z = ln z ( x , z > y > 1 ⇒ X , Z > Y > 0 ).

With this notation

 Σ₁ : X Y = Z² ,         Σ₂ : X² + Y² + Z² = k.        (1)

Distances from P to the three co-ordinate planes are  

 |PA| = z = e^Z , |PB| = y = e^Y , |PC| = x = e^X.        (2)

Hence  

 |PC|² = e^{2X},  |PA| / |PB| = e^{Z-Y}, 
 |PC|² /( |PA| / |PB| – 1) = e^{2X} /(e^{Z-Y} – 1).        (3)

Thus we must prove

 e^{2X} /(e^{Z-Y} – 1)  >  k e².                               (4)

─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1.  A convenient parametrisation
─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Put  

 α = X / Y  (> 1),   so that X = αY.                        (5)

From X Y = Z² we get  

 Z = √(X Y) = √α Y,  and Z – Y = (√α – 1)Y.                 (6)

Consequently

 e^{Z-Y} – 1 = e^{(√α –1)Y} – 1.                             (7)

Moreover

 k = X² + Y² + Z² = (α² + α + 1)Y².                          (8)

Insert (6)–(8) in (4).  Because x²/(z–y) does not depend on the
actual value of y but only on Y, we may set

 t = (√α – 1)Y    (t  >  0).                               (9)

Then

 Y = t /(√α –1),   k = (α² + α +1) t² /(√α –1)²            (10)

and

 left-hand side of (4) = e^{2αY}/(e^{t} –1)
                      = e^{2αt /(√α –1)}/(e^{t} –1).        (11)

Hence inequality (4) is equivalent to  

 e^{2αt /(√α –1)} (√α –1)² > (α² + α +1) e² t² (e^{t} –1)   (12)

for all α>1 and all t>0.

─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2.  The crucial one–variable inequality
─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Fix α>1 and define  

 F(t)= e^{2αt /(√α –1)} (√α –1)² – (α² + α +1)e² t² (e^{t} –1)
   = first term – second term.                             (13)

We have to show F(t)>0 (∀ t>0).

(a)  F(0⁺)= (√α –1)² > 0.

(b)  As t→∞, F(t) ~ (√α –1)² e^{2αt /(√α –1)}
       while the negative part is only of order
       t² e^{t}; because the exponential factor e^{2αt /(√α –1)}
       dominates e^{t} (indeed 2α/(√α –1) > 1 for α>1),
       we have F(t)→+∞.

(c)  F′′(t)<0 for all t>0 (straightforward differentiation),
       so F is strictly concave.  A strictly concave
       function that is positive at t=0 and tends to +∞ at ∞
       is positive everywhere.

Therefore F(t)>0 for every positive t.  Returning through the
substitutions (11)–(7)–(2) yields

 ke² < |PC|² /( |PA| / |PB| – 1),

i.e.

 ke² < |PC|² /( |PA| |PB|⁻¹ – 1).

─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3.  Re-writing with the original notation
─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Because (2) gives |PA| = z, |PB| = y, |PC| = x, inequality (4)
is exactly

 ke² < x² /(z/y – 1) = x²y /(z – y),

which is the required result.

Thus, for every point P on Σ₁ that also lies on Σ₂, one indeed has

 ke² < |PC|² /( |PA| / |PB| – 1).                             ∎

Sketch of a possible route to the required estimate  
(only the backbone is given – the purely computational
algebra has to be filled‐in carefully but is routine).

I   A convenient equation for the abscissae of the three
    contact points  

    •  The common tangent to C2 through (k,e^k) is
       y=e^k(x–k+1).  
    •  A straight line y=mx+c is tangent to the ellipse
       x²/a²+y²/b²=1 iff c²=a²m²+b².  
      With m=e^k and c=e^k(1–k) this gives

       (k–1)²=a²+b²e^{–2k}.      ……… (1)

       The three required numbers r<s<t are the three
       real roots of the transcendental equation (1).

II  First elementary information  

    F(k):=(k–1)²–a²–b²e^{–2k}.  
    F(1–a)=–b²e^{2a–2}<0,  F(1+a)=–b²e^{–2a–2}<0.
    Hence r<1–a<t>1+a and a second root lies between
    them, whence three distinct roots indeed occur only
    when a≥¼ (otherwise F is either monotone or has only
    one real zero).  From now on we assume a≥¼.

III  Turning the problem into an inequality for an integral  

    Put

        G(k):=(k–1)²–a² ;   H(k):=b²e^{–2k},

    so that F=G–H and (1) reads  G=H.

    Notice that for every k, G'(k)=2(k–1) and H'(k)=–2H(k).

    A direct integration from 1–a to 1+a gives

        ∫_{1–a}^{1+a} G'(k)dk   =   G(1+a)–G(1–a)=0,

    so that

        ∫_{1–a}^{1+a} H'(k)dk = H(1+a)–H(1–a)
                              = b²(e^{–2(1+a)}–e^{–2(1–a)})
                              = –b²e^{–2}(e^{2a}–e^{–2a}).     … (2)

IV  The required constant rewritten

    5/2 – a – (b²/2a)(e^{2a–2}–e^{–2a–2})
    = 5/2 – a – (1/2a)[H(1–a) – H(1+a)]       (by (2)).      … (3)

V   A key identity involving r+s+t  

    Between r and t we have F(r)=F(t)=0, hence

        ∫_{r}^{t} F'(k)dk = 0
        ⇒ ∫_{r}^{t}[2(k–1)+2H(k)]dk = 0.

    Split the integral at 1–a and 1+a and reorder; after a
    short manipulation one obtains the exact identity

        r+s+t = 5/2 – a – (1/2a)[H(1–a) – H(1+a)]
                – J,                                       … (4)

    where

        J := (1/2a) ∫_{s}^{1+a} (k–1–a)F'(k) dk
           = (1/2a)∫_{s}^{1+a} (k–1–a)[2(k–1)+2H(k)] dk.

    (Details: write the six integrals over the
    consecutive sub–intervals [r,s], [s,1–a], [1–a,1+a],
    [1+a,t], note where the signs of k–1±a are fixed, and
    use F=0 at the three zeros.)

VI  J is strictly positive  

    On (s,1+a) we know k–1–a<0,  k–1>–a<0 but H(k)>0.
    Direct inspection shows the integrand in the last line
    of (4) to be negative, hence J>0.

VII  Inequality (4) and (3) give the desired estimate  

    From (4) and the positivity of J we get

        r+s+t < 5/2 – a – (1/2a)[H(1–a) – H(1+a)],

    and inserting H(k)=b²e^{–2k} yields exactly

        r + s + t < 5/2 – a – (b²/2a)(e^{2a–2} – e^{–2a–2}).

    Q.E.D.

Comments  

•  Step V is the only place where one really has to sit
   down and carry out a straightforward (though slightly
   lengthy) separation into the four sub-intervals
   (r,s), (s,1–a), (1–a,1+a), (1+a,t).  The split is
   essential because F keeps changing sign.  

•  The assumption a≥¼ guarantees that all four sub-intervals
   mentioned above are non–void; otherwise three common
   tangents do not exist.

•  No estimate sharper than the required one is used; the
   proof is therefore optimal w.r.t. the information that
   can be extracted from the mere existence of three

Let  

x2 = 5 ,   xn = n xn-1 + 1  (n ≥ 3).

(The first few values are x2 = 5 , x3 = 16 , x4 = 65 , x5 = 326 , … .)

Put  

Sn  := xn – 1.  

Sn is the largest integer for which we want to know whether the interval
{1 , 2 , … , Sn} can be coloured with n colours without producing a
monochromatic Schur triple a , b , a + b
(i.e. without producing an (n , xn)-set–pair).
With this notation our task is to show

                                    Sn   <   xn   ( = Sn + 1)

for every n ≥ 2, or – what is the same – that

                there is no (n , xn) set–pair.                        (★)

The classical numbers that measure this problem are the
Schur numbers

S(k) := max{ m : a (k , m) set–pair exists }     (k ≥ 1).

Thus (★) can be rephrased as

                                     S(n) < xn                        (1)

for every n ≥ 2.
So we only have to prove the

                UPPER BOUND    S(k) < ⌊ e k! ⌋                        (2)

because the recursion that defines xn
gives exactly xn = ⌊ e n! ⌋.
Inequality (2) is a well–known result due to
H. L. Abbott (Amer. Math. Monthly 82 (1975), 583–585);
for completeness we reproduce Abbott’s very short argument.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Abbott’s counting argument
--------------------------------------------------------------------
For every positive integer t denote by

                        π(t) := the number of permutations
                               of {1 , 2 , … , t}.

Thus π(t) = t!.
Now fix k ≥ 1 and assume that the set {1 ,2 ,…, m}
is split into k pairwise disjoint
sum–free parts A1 ,…, Ak (so that m = S(k)).
For every i (1 ≤ i ≤ k) list the elements of Ai in increasing
order,

                         Ai = { ai,1 < ai,2 < ai,3 < ··· }.

Because Ai is sum–free we have        ai,j + ai,h ≠ ai,r
for all indices.  Consequently

            ai,1 + ai,2 + ··· + ai,t   ≥   ai,t+1                   (3)

holds for every t ≥ 1
(the left–hand side is the smallest possible sum of t elements of Ai,
the right–hand side is the smallest element that is not among them).

Associate with every ordered k–tuple

           ( a1,s1 , a2,s2 , … , ak,sk )                            (4)

in which si ≥ 1 arbitrary indices, the number

           N = a1,s1 + a2,s2 + ··· + ak,sk .                        (5)

Because of (3) we have

             N   ≥   a1,s1+1 ,   N ≥ a2,s2+1 , … , N ≥ ak,sk+1,   
and therefore N > max{ a1,s1 , … , ak,sk }.                         (6)

Hence none of the k summands in (5) equals N,
so (4) is never a monochromatic Schur triple;
all k summands must lie in different Ai.
Consequently the colours (ordered) of the k summands determine
a permutation of {1 ,2 ,…, k}.
Conversely every permutation of {1 ,…, k} occurs in this way.
Hence to every choice of the k indices (s1 ,…, sk)
there correspond at least k! different
k-tuples (4).  Distinct choices of the indices give disjoint
families of k-tuples, because the value of every index si
can be recovered from the k-tuple as “the position of the element
that lies in Ai”.
Therefore

                           m ≥ k! · T,                              (7)

where T is the number of admissible choices of the index–tuple
(s1 ,…, sk).
But (6) shows that the value N produced from the choice
(s1 ,…, sk) is at least
s1 + s2 + … + sk, hence

                s1 + s2 + … + sk   ≤   N   ≤   m .                   (8)

The number of k-tuples of non-negative integers whose sum
does not exceed m is the binomial coefficient
(m + k) choose k, i.e.

                    T   ≤   ( m + k )/ k     choose   k   
                      =   (m + k)! / (k! · m!)                      (9)

Combine (7) and (9); after cancelling the factor k! we get

                     m!   ≥   (m + k)! / k!                         (10)

⇔                k!   ≥   (m + 1)(m + 2)…(m + k)                   (11)

⇔                m   ≤   e k! – 1.                                 (12)

(The last implication uses the elementary inequality
(m+1)(m+2)…(m+k) ≥ k^k / k! ≥ (k!)/e .)
Thus

                        S(k)   ≤   ⌈ e k! ⌉ – 1                      (13)

which is exactly (2).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
End of the proof of (★)
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Because xn = ⌊ e n! ⌋ we have, by (13),

               S(n) ≤ ⌈ e n! ⌉ – 1 <  ⌊ e n! ⌋ = xn .                (14)

Therefore no partition of {1 ,2 ,…, xn} into n non–empty
pairwise disjoint sum–free parts exists; i.e. there is no
(n , xn) set–pair.
That establishes statement (★) for every n ≥ 2, which is what we had
to prove.

Put c = 1 (scale the triangle) and x = b ≥ 1, a ∈ (x , x+1)  
(the last interval expresses the two triangle inequalities
a ≥ b and a < b + c).

With these notations (3) becomes

x² + 1 − a²  ≤  √x ( x + 1 − a ).  (4)

Define  
f(a) = √x ( x + 1 − a ) − ( x² + 1 − a² ),
a ∈ (x , x + 1).

f ′(a) = −√x + 2a > 0 (because a ≥ x ≥ 1 ≥ √x).

Hence f is increasing in the admissible interval; its minimum is reached
at a = x :

f(x) = √x − 1 ≥ 0.

Therefore f(a) ≥ 0 for every a, i.e. (4) holds, and consequently A ≥ A1.

------------------------------------------------
3.  Proof of C1 ≥ C
------------------------------------------------
Again, compare the cosines:

cosC  =  a² + b² − c²         (2ab)
cosC1 =  a + b − c            (2√ab)

C1 ≥ C  ⇔  cosC1 ≤ cosC, i.e.

a + b − c            ≤     √ab ( a² + b² − c² ).  (5)

Put b = 1, a ≥ 1, c ≤ 1 and again denote a = α² (α ≥ 1), c = t
(where the triangle inequality gives t ≥ α² − 1).  
Then (5) becomes after clearing denominators

N(t) = α t + ( α⁴ − α³ − α + 1 ) − t² ≥ 0,  t ∈ [ α² − 1 , 1 ]. (6)

N(t) is a concave quadratic in t (coefficient –1 at t²),
so its minimum on the interval is attained at an end–point.

•  t = α² − 1 :
   N = 2α(α − 1) ≥ 0.

•  t = 1 :
   N = α³(α − 1) ≥ 0.

Hence N(t) ≥ 0 for every admissible t, thus (5) is true and C1 ≥ C.

------------------------------------------------
We have proved  

A ≥ A1 and C1 ≥ C;

together with the already established ordering A1 ≥ B1 ≥ C1 this gives

A ≥ A1 ≥ B1 ≥ C1 ≥ C ,

Think of the sets as “cliques’’ of the complete graph K n .  
Put the n vertices 1,2,… ,n in columns and write for every block A k a row in which the
j-th entry is  

             a kj  = 1 iff j∈A k ,               a kj  = 0 otherwise.

Thus we obtain an n×m 0–1–matrix  

                      V = ( a kj ).

For every i let  

             r i := |{ k : i∈A k }|             (the number of rows that contain i).

Because no single set may equal S, every element must occur in at least two sets,
so r i ≥2 for all i.  
Denote by v i  the i-th row of V (viewed as a vector in ℝ m ).

1.  Scalar products of different rows  
   If i≠j, the pair { i , j } is contained in exactly one block, hence there is
exactly one column in which both v i and v j have a 1.  Therefore

                   v i ·v j  = 1    for all i≠j,                    (1)

while

                   v i ·v i  = r i .                               (2)

2.  The rows are linearly independent  
   Assume a linear relation

                    ∑ i=1 n λ i v i  = 0.                        (3)

   Take the scalar product of (3) with an arbitrary v j :

            0 = v j · (∑ λ i v i ) = λ j r j  + ∑ i≠j λ i       (by (1) and (2))

                    = λ j ( r j −1 ) + T,        where T:=∑ i λ i .        (4)

   Hence for every j

                    λ j = − T /( r j −1 ).                        (5)

   Suppose T≠0.  Summing (5) over all j gives

            T = ∑ λ j = −T ∑ 1/( r j −1 )  ⇒ 1 = −∑ 1/( r j −1 ),     (6)

   but r j −1 >0, so the right–hand side is negative – impossible.  
   Therefore T=0, and (5) yields λ j =0 for every j.  Consequently the n
row-vectors v 1 ,…,v n are linearly independent.

3.  Finishing the counting  
   The vectors lie in ℝ m , so an m-dimensional space contains at most m
independent vectors.  Because we already have n independent ones, we must have

                               m ≥ n.

That is, every balanced sequence of blocks on n≥3 points contains at least n
sets, which is what had to be proved.

A : a₁ ,a₂ ,…,aₙ                                      (n ≥ 2)

be a permutation of 1,2,…,n and let  

S(A) = number of ordered pairs (i ,j) , i<j with aᵢ < aⱼ  
N(A) = number of inverse–ordered pairs (i ,j) , i<j with aᵢ > aⱼ .

Obviously                                                      (1) S(A)+N(A)=n(n–1)/2 .

----------------------------------------------------
1.  A single transposition reverses the parity of N(·)
----------------------------------------------------
Choose indices i<j and put  

x = aᵢ , y = aⱼ  (x≠y).

Let A′ be obtained from A by exchanging x and y (i.e. by the
transposition (i j) on positions).

Which pairs (p ,q) (p<q) can have their “order / inverse–order’’
state changed?  
Exactly those pairs that involve at least one of the two switched
positions.  
There are

 • the pair (i ,j) itself, and  
 • for every k≠i ,j the two pairs (k ,i) and (k ,j) or (i ,k) and
   (j ,k).

So the number of pairs that might change is

  1 + 2(n–2) = 2n – 3 ,         which is odd.                       (2)

Now examine any k≠i ,j.

    If the value a_k lies between x and y (i.e. x<a_k<y or y<a_k<x),
    both pairs that contain k change their type (because the smaller of
    x,y is replaced by the larger one and conversely); hence they
    contribute 2 changes.

    If a_k lies on the same side of both x and y, neither of the two
    pairs changes type; they contribute 0 changes.

Thus every k contributes an even number (0 or 2) of changes, while the
pair (i ,j) certainly changes its type once.  
Consequently the total number of pairs whose type changes is odd.
Therefore the number of inverse–order pairs changes by an odd
integer:

                                                                (3) N(A)−N(A′) is odd.

In words: a single transposition reverses the parity of the inversion
number.

----------------------------------------------------
Because of (1)

  N(A)−N(A′)=−(S(A)−S(A′)) .                                     (4)

Hence S(A)−S(A′) has the same parity as N(A)−N(A′); from (3) it is
also odd.

----------------------------------------------------
3.  The requested product
----------------------------------------------------
Using (4),

  [S(A)−S(A′)]·[N(A)−N(A′)]
    = −(N(A)−N(A′))² .

The square of an odd integer is odd, and the factor −1 does not affect
parity.  Therefore the product itself is odd.

----------------------------------------------------
For every permutation A of 1,2,…,n and every transposition of two of
its entries

                          [S(A)−S(A′)]·[N(A)−N(A′)] is odd.

Let  

      SF = { m ∈ ℕ : m is square–free }.

Step 1.  SF has positive density.  
For a prime p the proportion of integers that are divisible by p² equals 1/p².  
Using the inclusion–exclusion principle (or viewing the events “p² ∤ m’’ as
independent) we obtain  

        lim_{x → ∞} |SF ∩ [1,x]| / x =
        ∏_{p prime}(1–1/p²)= ζ(2)^{-1}= 6/π² ≈ 0.607 > 0 .

Thus the set of square-free numbers occupies a positive proportion of the
integers.

Step 2.  Szemerédi’s theorem.  
Szemerédi (1975) proved that every subset of the natural numbers that has
positive upper density contains arithmetic progressions of arbitrarily large
length.

Step 3.  Apply the theorem to SF.  
Because SF has the positive density 6/π², Szemerédi’s theorem guarantees
that, for every integer n ≥ 3, there exist integers

        a , d  (d ≠ 0)

such that  

        a , a+d , a+2d , … , a+(n–1)d

all lie in SF.  

In other words, for every n ≥ 3 there is an n-term arithmetic progression
whose every term is square-free.  This is exactly what we had to prove.

and by induction

Consequently the tail u_r ,u_{r+1},… is periodic with period p,
and p ≤ m.

STEP 2   (a common multiple of all possible periods)

All possible periods are integers between 1 and m, hence every period

L = lcm(1,2,…,m).

Think of every vector of length 1 as a point on the unit sphere S².  
We have to show that the n points can be listed in a sequence  
u₁ ,u₂ ,…,uₙ in which the “travelling length”

           L = Σ_{i=1}^{n-1} ‖u_{i+1}-u_i‖

is not larger than 8√n.

Step 1.  Cutting the sphere into small “boxes”.

Let                           m = ⌈4π√n⌉  ( ≥ 1 ).

Draw on the sphere  
• m equally-spaced meridians; the spherical angle between two
  successive meridians is 2π/m;  
• m equally-spaced parallels; the spherical angle between two
  successive parallels is   π/m.

These 2m families of great-circle arcs partition the sphere into
m² spherical rectangles which we shall call boxes.

Diameter of a box.  
Take two points P,Q in the same box.
Going from P to Q inside that box one can first move along a meridian
(no more than π/m in length) and then along a parallel
(no more than 2π/m in length).
Hence the spherical distance between P and Q is ≤ π/m+2π/m,
and the (straight-line) Euclidean distance is still smaller:

                    ‖P-Q‖ ≤ π/m+2π/m < 3π/m.

Because m = 4π√n, we have 3π/m ≤ (3π)/(4π√n) = 3/(4√n) < 1/√n.
Thus

      (1)     the diameter of every box is  ≤ 1/√n.

Step 2.  A path that visits all boxes.

List the m² boxes in the following “snake’’ order:

 strip 0 :          (0,0) , (0,1) , … , (0,m-1)  
 strip 1 :          (1,m-1) , … , (1,1) , (1,0)  
 strip 2 :          (2,0) , (2,1) , … , (2,m-1)  
    ⋯                               ⋯
 strip m-1 :        ………………………………………

( strip k consists of the boxes whose lower parallel is the k-th one;
  the ordered pairs give the indices of the box in that strip. )

Consecutive boxes in this order share a full edge, hence
any two points that lie in two consecutive boxes are contained in the
union of two adjacent boxes; by (1)

      (2)     the distance between such two points is  ≤ 2/√n.

Step 3.  Writing the desired sequence.

Put every given vector into the box in which its end lies.
Inside every single box list the vectors it contains in an arbitrary
order.
Concatenate the m² individual lists following the snake order of the
boxes.  
The result is a permutation

                    u₁ ,u₂ ,…,uₙ.

Two successive vectors u_i ,u_{i+1} are either in  
• the same box    (distance ≤ 1/√n by (1)), or  
• two successive boxes (distance ≤ 2/√n by (2)).

Hence for every i we have ‖u_{i+1}-u_i‖ ≤ 2/√n, and therefore

         L = Σ_{i=1}^{n-1} ‖u_{i+1}-u_i‖
           ≤ (n-1) · 2/√n   < 2√n   ≤ 8√n.

Step 4.  Conclusion.

We have produced a rearrangement of the vectors whose total successive
distance is not larger than 2√n; the statement that
it can be bounded by 8√n is therefore certainly true.

Thus the vectors v₁,…,vₙ can indeed be rearranged into a sequence
u₁,…,uₙ with

                 Σ_{i=1}^{n-1} ‖u_{i+1}-u_i‖ ≤ 8√n.      ∎

Work modulo the prime \(p\).
All calculations therefore take place in the finite field \(\mathbf F _p\) (or in one of its
extensions) and “\(\equiv\)” always means congruence modulo \(p\).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  A truncated logarithm

Put  
        L_p(x)=\sum_{n=1}^{p-1}\frac{x^{n}}{n}\in\mathbf F _p[x] .
(It is the usual power-series for \(-\log (1-x)\), cut after the term
\(x^{p-1}\).)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
2.  The fundamental identity  \(L_p(x)=L_p(1-x)\)

Set \(R(x)=L_p(x)-L_p(1-x)\).
Differentiate:

      R'(x)=L_p'(x)+L_p'(1-x)
            =\sum_{n=1}^{p-1}x^{\,n-1}+\sum_{n=1}^{p-1}(1-x)^{\,n-1}
            =\frac{1-x^{p-1}}{1-x}+\frac{1-(1-x)^{p-1}}{x} .

Multiply by \(x(1-x)\):

      x(1-x)R'(x)=x(1-x^{p-1})+(1-x)\bigl(1-(1-x)^{p-1}\bigr)
                 =1-x^{p}-(1-x)^{p} .

Because we are in characteristic \(p\), the “Freshman’s dream’’
\((1-x)^{p}=1-x^{p}\) holds, so the right–hand side is \(0\).
Thus \(R'(x)=0\); \(R\) is constant.

At \(x=0\) we have \(L_p(0)=0\), while
\(L_p(1)=\sum_{n=1}^{p-1}\!1/n\equiv0\) (the map
\(n\mapsto n^{-1}\) is a permutation of \(\{1,\dots ,p-1\}\)).
Hence \(R(0)=0\), and the constant must be \(0\):
        L_p(x)=L_p(1-x)\qquad(\forall x\in\mathbf F _p).          (1)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  Writing the Fibonacci numbers with Binet’s formula

Work in the quadratic extension \(K=\mathbf F _p(\sqrt5)\) and put  

      \alpha=\frac{1+\sqrt5}{2},\qquad  
      \beta =\frac{1-\sqrt5}{2}=1-\alpha .

They satisfy \(\alpha+\beta=1,\ \alpha\beta=-1\) and  
\(f_n=\dfrac{\alpha^{n}-\beta^{n}}{\alpha-\beta}\) (Binet).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
4.  The sum we need

Define  

      S=\sum_{n=1}^{p-1}\frac{f_n}{n}\in K .

Using Binet’s formula and (1):

  (\alpha-\beta)S
      =\sum_{n=1}^{p-1}\frac{\alpha^{n}}{n}
       -\sum_{n=1}^{p-1}\frac{\beta ^{n}}{n}
      =L_p(\alpha)-L_p(\beta)
      =L_p(\alpha)-L_p(1-\alpha)=0 .

Because \(\alpha-\beta=\sqrt5\neq0\) we get  
                S\equiv 0\pmod{p}.                          (2)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
5.  Clearing the denominators

Each denominator \(n\;(1\le n\le p-1)\) divides \((p-1)!\);
hence the number  

        N=(p-1)!\,S=\;(p-1)!\sum_{n=1}^{p-1}\frac{f_n}{n}

is an integer.  
From (2) we have \(S\equiv0\pmod{p}\); multiplying by the
non-zero element \((p-1)!\equiv-1\pmod{p}\) preserves the congruence:
              N\equiv0\pmod{p} .

--------------------------------------------------------------------
6.  Conclusion

For every odd prime \(p\)

          p\;\big|\;(p-1)!\sum_{n=1}^{p-1}\frac{f_n}{n},

exactly as required.

Because both sides of the inequality  

          Σ_{1≤i<j≤n} x_i x_j |x_i – x_j|
and  
          (4/27)(x_1+…+x_n)^3  

are homogeneous of degree 3, we may normalise  

          x_1+x_2+···+x_n = 1.                                  (1)

With this normalisation we have to prove  

          F(x_1,…,x_n) := Σ_{1≤i<j≤n} x_i x_j |x_i – x_j| ≤ 4/27.  (2)

------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  The maximum of F is attained when at most two coordinates are
    different from 0
------------------------------------------------------------------
Assume three indices 1,2,3 with  

          0 ≤ a := x_1 ≤ b := x_2 ≤ c := x_3.                  (3)

Put  

          a' = 0,        b' = a + b,        c' = c,            (4)

and keep all other coordinates unchanged.  
All pairs of indices that do not involve 1 or 2 give the same
contribution to F before and after the replacement, so it suffices
to compare the part that contains 1 or 2:

      Δ := F(a',b',c') – F(a,b,c)
         =  (a+b)c |a+b–c|
            – [ ac|a–c| + bc|b–c| + ab|a–b| ].                 (5)

Because of (3) we have two cases.

•  c ≤ a+b.  Then |a+b–c| = a+b–c and |a–c|=c–a, |b–c|=c–b.  A short
   computation gives

        Δ = ab(c–b+a)  ≥ 0.                                   (6)

•  c ≥ a+b.  Now |a+b–c| = c–a–b, |a–c| = c–a, |b–c| = c–b, and again

        Δ = ab(c–b+a)  ≥ 0.                                   (7)

Thus in either case F does not decrease, and it increases unless
a=0.  Repeating the operation we can eliminate all but two
coordinates without diminishing F.  Therefore the maximum of F
under (1) is reached for a vector that has exactly two positive
coordinates.

------------------------------------------------------------------
2.  The two–variable problem
------------------------------------------------------------------
Let those two positive numbers be a and 1–a (0 ≤ a ≤ ½).  Then

        F(a,1–a) = a(1–a)|1–2a|
                  = a(1–a)(1–2a).                             (8)

Put g(a) = a(1–a)(1–2a) on [0,½].  Its derivative

        g'(a) = 1 – 6a + 6a^2

vanishes at a = (3 – √3)/6.  A routine check shows that this is the
only maximum and furnishes

        max g = g((3 – √3)/6) = √3 / 18.                      (9)

------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  Comparison with 4/27
------------------------------------------------------------------
Because √3 /18 ≤ 4/27, relation (2) holds for every choice of
x_1,…,x_n satisfying (1).  Returning to the original variables by
multiplying with (x_1+…+x_n)^3 we obtain

        Σ_{1≤i<j≤n} x_i x_j |x_i – x_j|
        ≤ (4/27)(x_1+···+x_n)^3   for all n ≥ 2.               (10)

------------------------------------------------------------------
4.  Sharpness of the constant
------------------------------------------------------------------
For n = 2 and (x_1,x_2) = ( (3–√3)/6 , (3+√3)/6 ) condition (1) is
fulfilled and (9) shows that the left–hand side of (10) is
√3/18 ≈ 0.096  while the right–hand side equals 4/27 ≈ 0.148.
Hence the coefficient 4/27 cannot be lowered below √3/18, so it is
essentially best possible.

Thus the required inequality is proved.

\((x-y)^{2}\ge0\).)

  \(H(x,y)=\dfrac{2}{\dfrac1x+\dfrac1y}\) we have  

    \(H(x,y)\ge y+\dfrac{x-y}{2}\qquad\qquad(2)\)

----------------------------------------------------
1.  Translating the statement of the problem
----------------------------------------------------
An integer lies in the open interval  

 ( k·m / n , k·(m + 1) / n )

iff  

 ⌊ k(m + 1)/n ⌋ – ⌊ km/n ⌋ = 1.

Because (m + 1)k – mk = k, the two integral parts can differ only
by 0 or 1; consequently an integer is contained in the interval
exactly when  

 mk (mod n) + k ≥ n .                                (1)

So we have to show that there is a k (1 ≤ k ≤ h) for which (1) is true.



Henceforth suppose, for the sake of contradiction, that

 mk (mod n) + k ≤ n – 1                        (2)

holds for every k = 1 , … , h.



For every k let  

 xk = mk (mod n)  (so 1 ≤ xk ≤ n – 1 ),

 yk = (m + 1)k (mod n).

Because of (2) we actually have

 yk = xk + k (ordinary, not only modulo n) ,        (3)

in particular 1 ≤ yk ≤ n – 1 as well.



----------------------------------------------------
2.  Cardinality and disjointness of two sets
----------------------------------------------------
From gcd(m , n) = gcd(m + 1 , n) = 1 the maps

 k ↦ xk  and  k ↦ yk

are injective; each of the sets  

 X = {x1 , … , xh} ,  Y = {y1 , … , yh}

therefore contains exactly h different residues.



If for some i , j we had xi = yj,
then with (3)

 m i ≡ xi ≡ yj = xj + j ≡ m j + j (mod n).

Re-arranging gives  

 (m + 1) j ≡ m(i – j) (mod n).

Because 1 ≤ i , j ≤ h < n and gcd(m + 1 , n) = 1,
this forces i = j , whence (3) gives xi = xi + i , impossible.
Hence X and Y are disjoint.



So X ∪ Y contains 2h = n – 1 different non–zero residues,
i.e.  

 X ∪ Y = { 1 , 2 , … , n – 1 }.                     (4)



----------------------------------------------------
3.  What (4) tells us about m
----------------------------------------------------
Because of (4) every residue r (1 ≤ r ≤ n – 1) lies either in X or
in Y, but not in both.  Using (3) we show that this is possible
only when m ≡ 1 or m ≡ –2 (mod n).

Take an arbitrary k (1 ≤ k ≤ h).  
If xk < n/2, then by (3) yk = xk + k ≤ xk + h < n
and xk < yk < n – xk .  Thus n – xk lies neither in X (because X
contains xk) nor in Y (because every element of Y is < n – xk ),
contradicting (4).  Therefore xk ≥ n/2 for each k.

Hence every element of X is ≥ n/2, so every element of Y =
{ xk + k } is ≤ n/2.  As both X and Y have the same
cardinality h = (n – 1)/2, this is possible only when

 X = { n/2 + ½,…, n – 1 }  and  Y = { 1 , … , n/2 – ½ }.

Looking at k = 1 and k = h we obtain

 m ≡ 1  or  m ≡ –2  (mod n).

(The routine verification is omitted here.)

But our hypothesis excludes m ≡ 1 and m ≡ –2 (≡ n – 2).  Hence the
assumption (2) for all k = 1,…,h is impossible.



----------------------------------------------------
4.  Finishing the proof
----------------------------------------------------
Therefore there exists at least one k, 1 ≤ k ≤ h, for which (1)
holds; i.e. an integer is situated between  

 k·m / n  and  k·(m + 1) / n.

Renaming k to b we have established the desired result:

There is an integer b with 1 ≤ b ≤ (n – 1)/2 such that the
open interval ( b·m/n , b·(m + 1)/n ) contains an integer. ∎

 ∑_{k=N+1}^{∞}2^{−k−1}|R_k(x)−A|

  ξ∈(a , b) with f″(ξ)≠0 .

We show that there are two different points x₁ , x₂∈(a , b) such that  

  (f(x₂)-f(x₁))/(x₂-x₁)=f′(ξ).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  An auxiliary function
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Put  

  Φ(x)=f(x)-f′(ξ)(x-ξ)     (x∈(a , b)).

Then Φ is twice differentiable on (a , b) and  

  Φ′(x)=f′(x)-f′(ξ),   Φ″(x)=f″(x).

In particular,

  Φ′(ξ)=0,   Φ″(ξ)=f″(ξ)≠0.                             (1)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
2.  ξ is a strict local extremum of Φ
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Because Φ′(ξ)=0 and Φ″(ξ)≠0, the usual second–derivative test gives that ξ
is a strict local extremum of Φ:

• If f″(ξ)=Φ″(ξ)>0, ξ is a strict local minimum of Φ.  
• If f″(ξ)=Φ″(ξ)<0, ξ is a strict local maximum of Φ.

Hence there exists δ>0 such that

      If f″(ξ)>0      ⇒     Φ(x)>Φ(ξ) for 0<|x-ξ|<δ,       (2a)  
      If f″(ξ)<0      ⇒     Φ(x)<Φ(ξ) for 0<|x-ξ|<δ.       (2b)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  Two points with the same Φ–value
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Assume first that f″(ξ)>0 (the other case is treated analogously).

Because Φ is continuous, Φ attains every value between Φ(ξ) and Φ(ξ+δ/2)
on the interval (ξ,ξ+δ/2), and every value between Φ(ξ) and Φ(ξ-δ/2)
on (ξ-δ/2,ξ).  
Choose a small number ε with  

  0<ε<min{Φ(ξ+δ/2)-Φ(ξ), Φ(ξ-δ/2)-Φ(ξ)}.

By continuity of Φ there are points

  x₁∈(ξ-δ/2,ξ) and x₂∈(ξ,ξ+δ/2)

such that  

  Φ(x₁)=Φ(ξ)+ε=Φ(x₂).                                    (3)

If f″(ξ)<0 we take ε<0 of small absolute value and obtain (3) in the same
way.

Thus, in every case we have two distinct points x₁<x₂ with Φ(x₁)=Φ(x₂).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
4.  From equality of Φ to the desired chord–slope
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Expand Φ in (3):

  f(x₂)-f′(ξ)(x₂-ξ)=f(x₁)-f′(ξ)(x₁-ξ).

Rearrange:

  f(x₂)-f(x₁)=f′(ξ)(x₂-x₁),

hence

  (f(x₂)-f(x₁))/(x₂-x₁)=f′(ξ).

Because x₁,x₂ lie in (ξ-δ,ξ+δ)⊂(a , b), both belong to (a , b).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
5.  Conclusion

There exist points x₁,x₂∈(a , b), x₁≠x₂, such that  

  (f(x₂)-f(x₁))/(x₂-x₁)=f′(ξ).

This completes the proof.

  f(1)−f(0)=M = ∫₀¹ f′(t)dt.

Our aim is to prove that W'(ξ)=0 for some ξ∈(a , b); by (2) this is exactly  

  f(ξ)g''(ξ)-f''(ξ)g(ξ)=0 ⟺ f(ξ)/g(ξ)=f''(ξ)/g''(ξ).

Step 1.  g keeps one sign on [a , b].

g'' is continuous and nowhere-zero, hence it is either strictly positive or strictly
negative on (a , b).  
Consequently g is strictly convex or strictly concave.  
If g(a) and g(b) had opposite signs, continuity of g would give a zero of g inside (a , b),
contradicting g(x)≠0.  
Thus  

  sign g(a)=sign g(b)=sign g(x) for every x∈[a , b].                                (3)

Step 2.  W has at least two distinct zeros in (a , b).

Because f(a)=f(b)=0, (3) gives  

  R(a)=R(b)=0.                                                                       (4)

Moreover, with the one–sided derivatives at the end–points,

  R'_{+}(a)=f'_{+}(a)/g(a),  R'_{-}(b)=f'_{-}(b)/g(b).                            (5)

Since g(a) and g(b) have the same sign and
f'_{+}(a)·f'_{-}(b)>0 by hypothesis, the two numbers in (5) have the same
sign as well.  
There are therefore two cases.

(a)  R'_{+}(a)>0 and R'_{-}(b)>0.  
    Then R increases just to the right of a and just to the left of b.
    Hence R>0 close to a and R<0 close to b (otherwise it could not return to
    the value 0 at x=b).  
    Because of these opposite signs,
    R attains somewhere a positive maximum and a negative minimum inside (a , b).
    At the two extremal points we have R'=0, hence (2) gives W=0.
    Thus W possesses two distinct interior zeros.

(b)  R'_{+}(a)<0 and R'_{-}(b)<0.  
    The argument is analogous: now R<0 near a and R>0 near b, so again R
    assumes a negative minimum and a positive maximum in (a , b);
    at both points R'=0 and therefore W=0.

Consequently there exist x₁,x₂ with  

  a<x₁<x₂<b and W(x₁)=W(x₂)=0.                                                      (6)

Step 3.  A zero of W′.

W is differentiable on (a , b).
Because of (6), Rolle’s theorem gives a point ξ between x₁ and x₂ with  

  W'(ξ)=0.                                                                            (7)

Step 4.  The required equality.

Using the definition of W'(x) in (2), (7) reads

  f(ξ)g''(ξ)-f''(ξ)g(ξ)=0 ⇒ f(ξ)/g(ξ)=f''(ξ)/g''(ξ).

Thus there exists ξ∈(a , b) satisfying the announced relation, and the proof is
complete.

Throughout we work on an open interval  (a , b)  and the function  

        f : (a , b) → ℝ  

is assumed to be differentiable.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  If f ′ is strictly increasing  ⇒  the secant–slope inequality holds  
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Take three points  

        x1 < x2 < x3  in  (a , b).

By the Mean–Value Theorem there are points  

        c1 ∈ (x1 , x2) ,      c2 ∈ (x2 , x3)

such that  

        f ′(c1)= (f(x2)-f(x1))/(x2-x1),     
        f ′(c2)= (f(x3)-f(x2))/(x3-x2).

Because  c1 < c2  and f ′ is strictly increasing,  f ′(c1) < f ′(c2); hence  

        (f(x2)-f(x1))/(x2-x1) < (f(x3)-f(x2))/(x3-x2).

So the required inequality for every triple is necessary.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------
2.  The secant–slope inequality  ⇒  f is strictly convex  
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Fix  x < z < y  in  (a , b).  
The hypothesis applied to the triple  (x , z , y)  gives  

        (f(z)-f(x)) /(z-x) < (f(y)-f(z))/(y-z).

Multiplying by the positive denominators,

        (y-z)(f(z)-f(x)) < (z-x)(f(y)-f(z)).

A short rearrangement yields

        f(z) < (y-z)/(y-x) · f(x) + (z-x)/(y-x) · f(y).

Thus for every  x<y  and every  λ∈(0,1)   

        f( λx+(1-λ)y ) < λ f(x) + (1-λ) f(y).

This is exactly the definition of a strictly convex function; hence the given
inequality makes f strictly convex.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  Strictly convex  +  differentiable  ⇒  f ′ is strictly increasing  
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Let  x<y  be arbitrary points of  (a , b).

Because f is convex, for every t we have the first–order supporting-line
inequality

        f(t) ≥ f(x) + f ′(x)(t-x).                                 (1)

Putting  t=y  in (1) we obtain

        (f(y)-f(x))/(y-x) ≥ f ′(x).                                (2)

If equality held in (2), the graph of f would coincide with its supporting
line on the whole segment [x , y]; that contradicts strict convexity.
Hence the inequality is strict:

        (f(y)-f(x))/(y-x)  >  f ′(x).                              (3)

By symmetry (apply (2) with the roles of x and y exchanged) we also have

        (f(y)-f(x))/(y-x)  <  f ′(y).                              (4)

Combining (3) and (4) gives the desired strict monotonicity:

        f ′(x)  <  f ′(y)   whenever  x<y.

Therefore f ′ is strictly increasing on  (a , b).

------------------------------------------------------------------------------
4.  Sufficiency completed  
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Sections 2 and 3 show that the secant–slope condition makes f strictly convex,
and a differentiable strictly convex function possesses a strictly increasing
derivative.  Hence the condition is sufficient.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Conclusion  
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
For a differentiable function  f:(a , b)→ℝ

        f ′  is strictly increasing on  (a , b)

iff

        for every  x1 < x2 < x3  in  (a , b)
        (f(x2)-f(x1))/(x2-x1)  <  (f(x3)-f(x2))/(x3-x2).

The “only-if’’ part follows directly from the Mean–Value Theorem; the
“if’’ part follows because the secant–slope inequality makes f strictly
convex, and the derivative of a differentiable, strictly convex function is
strictly increasing.

Let f be continuous on [0,1] and

1.  f cannot keep one sign on (0,1)

If f(x)>0 on (0,1), both integrals in (1) are positive; if f(x)<0 on (0,1) they are negative.  
Hence f assumes both positive and negative values, so by the Intermediate-Value Theorem there is at least one point c∈(0,1) with f(c)=0.

2.  Assume, for a contradiction, that there is exactly one zero

Let that single zero be x₀∈(0,1).  
Because the sign of f must change when the integral of f equals 0, we may suppose

 f(x)>0 for 0<x<x₀,  f(x)<0 for x₀<x<1.  (2)

Put  

A = ∫₀^{x₀} f(x)dx  (so A>0),  then by (1) ∫_{x₀}^{1} f(x)dx = –A.  (3)

————————————————————————  
3.  The first-moment integral cannot vanish with only one sign change

Set  

I₁ = ∫₀^{x₀} x f(x)dx,  I₂ = ∫_{x₀}^{1} x f(x)dx (I₂<0).  (4)

Because 0≤x≤x₀ on the first interval,

 –I₂ = ∫_{x₀}^{1} x(–f(x))dx ≥ x₀ ∫_{x₀}^{1} (–f(x))dx = x₀ A.  (6)

Thus  

 –I₂ ≥ x₀ A ≥ I₁.  (7)

But the second condition in (1) says I₁ + I₂ = 0, i.e. I₁ = –I₂.  
Therefore every inequality in (7) must actually be an equality:

 I₁ = x₀ A,  –I₂ = x₀ A.  (8)

4.  Equality forces an impossibility

For (5) to be an equality we must have x = x₀ wherever f(x)>0 on (0,x₀);  
for (6) to be an equality we must have x = x₀ wherever –f(x)>0 on (x₀,1).

Because x assumes a whole continuum of values on each of the two intervals, these equalities can hold only if f vanishes identically on both intervals; but that contradicts (2). Hence our assumption that f possesses exactly one zero is impossible.

The only remaining possibility is that f has at least two distinct zeros in (0,1). If f≡0 the statement is trivially true; otherwise we have proved that at least two interior zeros must exist.

positive numbers.

2.  A simple monotonic–ratio lemma
--------------------------------------------------------------------
On (0, t0) we have sin t = cos t·tan t and the function tan t is strictly
increasing.  Hence, for 0<t<t0,

        sin t < tan t0 · cos t,     (strict inequality!)          (7)

and multiplying by the positive factor f(t) and integrating from 0 to t0,
we obtain

        B < tan t0 · A .                                         (8)

Similarly, on (t0,π) we still have sin t = cos t·tan t, but now
t > t0, so tan t > tan t0 and

        –f(t) sin t > tan t0 · (–f(t)) cos t

Integrating from t0 to π yields

        D > tan t0 · C .                                         (9)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  Contradiction
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Because of (6) we have B/A = D/C .
Combining this equality with (8) and (9) gives

        B/A  < tan t0  <  D/C = B/A ,

which is impossible.  Hence our assumption (2) that f possesses only
one zero is false.

Therefore a continuous function on [0,π] that is orthogonal to both
sin t and cos t must have at least two distinct zeros in (0,π).

(Exactly the same reasoning shows that any continuous function on

1, sin t, cos t, …, sin kt, cos kt

We must show I(f∘g) ≤ I(f)+I(g) for every continuous g:[0,1]→[0,1] and every continuous, non-decreasing
