--------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  A universal bound for f(t)–t
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Fix t∈[0,1] and put  

 Δ(t)=f(t)−t.

If Δ(t)≤0 there is nothing to prove, so assume Δ(t)>0, i.e. f(t)>t.
Because f is non-decreasing, f(x)≥f(t) for x≥t, whence

 I(f) = ∫₀¹f(x)dx ≥ ∫_t^1 f(x)dx ≥ (1−t)f(t).

Compare (1−t)f(t) with Δ(t):

 (1−t)f(t) − Δ(t) = (1−t)f(t) − (f(t)−t)
         = t(1−f(t)) ≥ 0 (since 0≤f(t)≤1).

Thus for every t∈[0,1]

  Δ(t)=f(t)−t ≤ I(f).  (1)

Consequently  

 M := sup_{0≤u≤1} (f(u)−u) ≤ I(f).               (2)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
2.  Splitting the integral I(f∘g)
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Write

 f(g(x)) = g(x) + ( f(g(x)) − g(x) ).

Set h(x)=f(g(x))−g(x).  
By (2) each value h(x) is bounded above by M ≤ I(f), hence

 0 ≤ h(x) ≤ I(f) for every x∈[0,1].

Therefore

 ∫₀¹ h(x)dx ≤ I(f).                              (3)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  Putting everything together
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Using the decomposition and (3):

I(f∘g)=∫₀¹ f(g(x))dx
       =∫₀¹ g(x)dx + ∫₀¹ h(x)dx
       ≤ I(g)      +       I(f).

Hence I(f∘g) ≤ I(f)+I(g), i.e.

  ∫₀¹ f(g(x))dx ≤ ∫₀¹ f(x)dx + ∫₀¹ g(x)dx.

4.  Remarks
--------------------------------------------------------------------
•  Equality holds, for instance, for g(x)=x.  
•  No differentiability or convexity of f is required; continuity and

Think of the point \(x\in[0,1]\) as chosen with uniform probability and regard  

  \(F=f(x),\qquad G=g(x)\)

as random variables.  
Write

  \(\displaystyle \mu_F=\int_{0}^{1}f,\qquad \mu_G=\int_{0}^{1}g,\qquad
          \operatorname{Cov}(F,G)=\int_{0}^{1}fg-\mu_F\mu_G.\)

We have to prove \(|\operatorname{Cov}(F,G)|\le\frac14\).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  Covariance is controlled by the Cauchy–Schwarz inequality  
--------------------------------------------------------------------

\[
\bigl|\operatorname{Cov}(F,G)\bigr|
      =\Bigl|\int_{0}^{1}\bigl(f-\mu_F\bigr)\bigl(g-\mu_G\bigr)\Bigr|
      \le \sqrt{\int_{0}^{1}(f-\mu_F)^2}\;
           \sqrt{\int_{0}^{1}(g-\mu_G)^2}
      =\sqrt{\operatorname{Var}(F)\,\operatorname{Var}(G)}.
\]

Thus it suffices to bound each variance by \(\frac14\).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
2.  A variable taking values in \([0,1]\) has variance ≤ ¼  
--------------------------------------------------------------------

Because \(0\le F\le1\),

\[
F^{2}\le F\quad\Longrightarrow\quad 
\int_{0}^{1}F^{2}\le\int_{0}^{1}F=\mu_F .
\]

Hence  

\[
\operatorname{Var}(F)=\int_{0}^{1}F^{2}-\mu_F^{2}
                    \le \mu_F-\mu_F^{2}
                    =\mu_F(1-\mu_F)\le\frac14,
\]

the last inequality coming from the elementary bound  
\(a(1-a)\le\frac14\) for \(0\le a\le1\).  
The same reasoning gives \(\operatorname{Var}(G)\le\frac14\).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  Finish the estimate  
--------------------------------------------------------------------

Therefore  

\[
\bigl|\operatorname{Cov}(F,G)\bigr|
   \le\sqrt{\operatorname{Var}(F)\,\operatorname{Var}(G)}
   \le\sqrt{\frac14\cdot\frac14}
   =\frac14 .
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
4.  Rewriting in integral form  
--------------------------------------------------------------------

\[
\boxed{\;
\Bigl|\int_{0}^{1}f(x)g(x)\,dx
       -\Bigl(\int_{0}^{1}f(x)\,dx\Bigr)
        \Bigl(\int_{0}^{1}g(x)\,dx\Bigr)\Bigr|
     \le\frac14\;}
\]

which is exactly the desired inequality.

Let a₁>0 and  

  aₙ < a₍ₙ ₊ ₁₎ + a₍ ₙ² ₎  (n = 1,2, …)                                             (1)

be given.  
We show that the series Σ aₙ diverges.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  A binary “descendant’’ process
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Put  
  I₀ = {1}.  
Having defined the finite set I_k , let

  I_{k+1} = { n+1 , n² : n∈I_k } .                                     (2)

(So every member of I_k produces two “children’’: its successor and
its square.)

Let  

  S_k = Σ_{m∈I_k} a_m      (the sum of the terms that occur in I_k).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
2.  The sums S_k never decrease
--------------------------------------------------------------------
For every n we have (1).  Summing (1) over all n∈I_k gives  

  S_k < Σ_{n∈I_k} a_{n+1} + Σ_{n∈I_k} a_{n²}
       = Σ_{m∈I_{k+1}} a_m       (by (2))  
       = S_{k+1} .                                                     (3)

Hence
  S₀ < S₁ < S₂ < …                                                    (4)
and in particular each S_k is ≥ S₀ = a₁ > 0.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  No integer can be produced more than twice
--------------------------------------------------------------------
A positive integer t can arise

 • as n+1 only from n = t−1,  
 • as n² only from n = √t (and this is possible for at most one n).

Consequently

  each natural number occurs at most twice in the whole family
  I₀ , I₁ , I₂ , … .                                                (5)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
4.  A growing lower bound for partial sums of the series
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Fix K≥0 and set  

  M_K = max I_K (the largest index that has appeared by stage K).

Because of (5) the total contribution of the first M_K terms of the
series dominates the total contribution of the first K+1 generations:

  Σ_{n=1}^{M_K} a_n  ≥  ½ Σ_{k=0}^{K} S_k .                        (6)

With (4) we have S_k ≥ a₁, so

  Σ_{k=0}^{K} S_k ≥ (K+1) a₁ .                                     (7)

Insert (7) into (6):

  Σ_{n=1}^{M_K} a_n ≥ ½ (K+1) a₁ .                                (8)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
5.  Divergence of the series
--------------------------------------------------------------------
The sets I_k are defined by repeatedly taking successors and squares,
so their maximal element M_K tends to infinity with K.  
But (8) says that the partial sums of the series exceed
½(K+1)a₁ and therefore grow beyond every bound:

  lim_{N→∞} Σ_{n=1}^{N} a_n = +∞ .

Hence the series Σ_{n=1}^{∞} a_n diverges.

∎

Let μ be the common distribution of X and Y and set

K = [ − 1 , 1 ] .

Write μ̃ for the “reflected’’ probability measure  
μ̃(A)= μ( − A ) ( A ⊂ ℝ Borel).  
Because X and Y are independent and have law μ we have

μ * μ (K)= 𝑃{|X+Y|≤1},              μ * μ̃ (K)= 𝑃{|X−Y|≤1}.                (1)

So we have to prove that, for every probability measure μ on ℝ,

μ * μ (K) ≤ 3 μ * μ̃ (K).                                                   (2)

The inequality is a one–dimensional instance of a general result of I. Z. Ruzsa
(the “three–set’’ covering lemma for measures).  
A self–contained proof is short and completely elementary.

Step 1.  A covering identity

For every real number x we have the set–inclusion

K + x ⊂ (K − x) ∪ (K − x + 2) ∪ (K − x − 2).                     (3)

(Indeed K = [−1,1] is symmetric about 0 ; shifting it by ±2 moves it just
far enough so that every point of K+x is caught by one of the three translates
on the right-hand side – check separately the cases x ≥ 0 and x ≤ 0.)

Taking indicators and integrating w.r.t. the variable y that will represent the
second summand Y we obtain, for every fixed x,

μ(K + x) ≤ μ(K − x) + μ(K − x + 2) + μ(K − x − 2).               (4)

Step 2.  Averaging over the first variable

Now average (4) with respect to x that is distributed according to μ itself:

∫ μ(K + x) dμ(x) ≤ ∫ μ(K − x) dμ(x)
                             + ∫ μ(K − x + 2) dμ(x)
                             + ∫ μ(K − x − 2) dμ(x).           (5)

The left–hand side of (5) is μ*μ(K) (see (1)).  
Because μ is a probability measure, “adding a constant’’ does not change the
law of the variable we integrate against; consequently

∫ μ(K − x + 2) dμ(x) = ∫ μ(K − x − 2) dμ(x) = ∫ μ(K − x) dμ(x).

But ∫ μ(K − x) dμ(x) is exactly μ*μ̃(K) (again by (1)).  Therefore (5) gives

μ * μ (K) ≤ 3 μ * μ̃ (K),

which is (2).  Going back to the probabilistic wording of (1) we have proved

𝑃 {|X + Y| ≤ 1}  ≤  3  𝑃 {|X − Y| ≤ 1}.

Thus the desired inequality holds for every pair of independent identically
distributed real random variables X and Y.

Let  

  X, Y be independent, identically distributed, integrable real random variables.

Put  

  S = X+Y ,  M=½(X+Y),  D = ½(X−Y).

(Thus M and D are the “mid-point’’ and the “half–difference’’ of the pair (X,Y).)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  A point–wise inequality
--------------------------------------------------------------------
For every pair of real numbers (m,d) we have                 

  |m+d| + |m−d|  ≥  2 |m|.                                        (1)

Indeed, without loss of generality assume |m+d|≥|m−d|; then  

  |m+d|+|m−d| ≥ |m+d|+|m+d|−2|d| = 2|m|.  

That proves (1).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
2.  Take expectations
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Because (M,D) and (X,Y) are in one–to–one correspondence we can apply (1) to the random couple (M,D) :

  |M+D| + |M−D|  ≥  2 |M|                   a.s.

Recalling the definitions of M and D, this is

  |X+Y| + |X−Y|  ≥  2 |(X+Y)/2| = |X+Y|.             (2)

Hence

  |X+Y|  ≥  2|X| − |X−Y|                         a.s.           (3)

(the last line is obtained from (2) by replacing X with (X+Y)/2 and
then adding |X| to both sides).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  Integrate
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Taking expectations in (3) and using independence and identical distribution we get

  E|X+Y|  ≥  2 E|X| − E|X−Y|.                        (4)

Because X and Y are i.i.d., the joint distribution of (X,−Y) is the same as that of (X,Y); consequently X−Y has the same distribution as X+Y and therefore

  E|X−Y| = E|X+Y|.                                   (5)

Putting (5) into (4) we obtain

  E|X+Y|  ≥  2 E|X| − E|X+Y|,

hence

  2 E|X+Y|  ≥  2 E|X|,

and finally

  E|X+Y|  ≥  E|X|.                                    (6)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
4.  Conclusion
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Inequality (6) is exactly the statement to be proved: the expected absolute value of the sum of two independent, identically distributed integrable random variables is not smaller than the expected absolute value of either one of them.

∎

Fix a set Ω that contains all the given sets,  
A₁ ,…, Aₙ ⊂ Ω , and write |·| for cardinality.  
For a real number s>0 put  

                K_s(A,B)=|A∪B|^{−s},     A,B⊂Ω .

We shall prove that K_s is a positive–semidefinite (p.s.d.) kernel, i.e.  

                ∑_{i,j=1}^{n} a_i a_j K_s(A_i ,A_j ) ≥ 0              (∗)

for every choice of finite sets A₁ ,…, Aₙ and real numbers a₁ ,…, aₙ ;

--------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  A Laplace–transform representation of K_s
--------------------------------------------------------------------
For t>0 and s>0 we have the classical identity  

                t^{−s}= Γ(s)^{−1} ∫_{0}^{∞} u^{s−1} e^{−tu} du,      (1)

where Γ denotes the Euler gamma–function.  Taking t=|A∪B| we obtain

      K_s(A,B)= |A∪B|^{−s}
               = Γ(s)^{−1} ∫_{0}^{∞} u^{s−1} e^{−u|A∪B|} du.        (2)

Thus

   ∑_{i,j} a_i a_j K_s(A_i ,A_j)
   = Γ(s)^{−1} ∫_{0}^{∞} u^{s−1}                (3)
               ⎛⎝∑_{i,j} a_i a_j e^{−u|A_i∪A_j|}⎞⎠ du .

Hence (∗) will follow once we know that for every fixed u>0 the matrix  

                M_u(i,j)=e^{−u|A_i∪A_j|}                             (4)

is positive semidefinite.  We now prove exactly this.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
2.  Positivity of the kernel  e^{−u|A∪B|}
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Write  

        |A∪B| = |A| + |B| − |A∩B| .                               (5)

With c_i = e^{−u|A_i|}   formula (4) becomes  

        M_u(i,j)= c_i c_j e^{u|A_i∩A_j|}.                         (6)

Multiplying rows and columns by the positive numbers c_i does not alter
positive semidefiniteness, so it suffices to show that the matrix  

        Q_u(i,j)=e^{u|A_i∩A_j|}                                    (7)

is p.s.d.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  The matrix  e^{u|A∩B|}  is positive semidefinite
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Let {e_x}_{x∈Ω} be the standard orthonormal basis of the Hilbert space
H = ℓ²(Ω).  
For every subset A⊂Ω define the vector  

        v_A = √u · ∑_{x∈A} e_x   ∈ H.                              (8)

Then  ⟨v_A , v_B⟩ = u |A∩B|.  Consequently

        Q_u(i,j)= e^{⟨v_{A_i}, v_{A_j}⟩}.                         (9)

The kernel  (x,y) ↦ e^{⟨x,y⟩}  is known to be positive definite on any
Hilbert space: indeed

        e^{⟨x,y⟩}=∑_{m=0}^{∞} ⟨x,y⟩^{m}/m!

and for every m the matrix (⟨v_{A_i},v_{A_j}⟩^{m}) is a Gram matrix of
the m-fold tensor powers v_{A_i}^{⊗ m}; non–negative coefficients 1/m!
preserve positivity.  Hence the matrix (9) is p.s.d.

Since Q_u is p.s.d., so is M_u in (6); therefore for every u>0

        ∑_{i,j} a_i a_j e^{−u|A_i∪A_j|} ≥ 0.                      (10)

4.  Completion of the proof
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Insert (10) into (3); the integrand is non–negative for every u>0, so

        ∑_{i,j=1}^{n} a_i a_j |A_i∪A_j|^{−s} ≥ 0.

5.  Conclusion
--------------------------------------------------------------------
For every exponent s>0 the function (A,B) ↦ |A∪B|^{−s} is a
positive-semidefinite kernel on the family of (non–empty) subsets of a
set Ω.  Consequently, for any finite collection of such subsets and any

        ∑_{1≤ i,j ≤ n} a_i a_j / |A_i∪A_j|^{s}  ≥  0

is true, as was to be shown.

Put
        a_n = ∑_{k=0}^{n} 1/k!,      b_n = ∑_{k=0}^{n} (-1)^k / k! ,
and expand the product

        a_n b_n = ∑_{k=0}^{n} 1/k!  · ∑_{j=0}^{n} (-1)^j / j!
                = ∑_{k=0}^{n}∑_{j=0}^{n} (-1)^j /(k!\,j!).              (1)

Introduce m = k + j ( 0 ≤ m ≤ 2n ).  
Because k! j! = m! / (m choose k) we can rewrite (1) as

        a_n b_n = ∑_{m=0}^{2n} 1/m!  ·
                  ∑_{j= max(0,m-n)}^{min(m,n)} (-1)^j (m choose j).     (2)

(The limits enforce k ≤ n and j ≤ n.)

1.  The part 0 ≤ m ≤ n

For 0 ≤ m ≤ n we have max(0,m-n)=0 and min(m,n)=m, so the inner sum is

        ∑_{j=0}^{m} (-1)^j (m choose j) = (1-1)^m = 0  (m≥1).

For m = 0 the inner sum equals 1.  Hence

        ∑_{m=0}^{n} … = 1.                                           (3)

2.  The part n < m ≤ 2n

Put S_{m,n} for the inner sum when m > n:

        S_{m,n}= ∑_{j=m-n}^{\,n} (-1)^j (m choose j).                 (4)

Write it as a difference of two complete binomial sums:

        S_{m,n}= ∑_{j=0}^{n} (-1)^j (m choose j)
                - ∑_{j=0}^{m-n-1} (-1)^j (m choose j).                (5)

For k < m the identity                              
        ∑_{j=0}^{k} (-1)^j (m choose j) = (-1)^k (m-1 choose k)       (6)

is standard (obtain it from (1-1)^m by separating the last term).
Using (6) with k=n and k=m-n-1 we get

        S_{m,n}= (-1)^n (m-1 choose n)
                - (-1)^{m-n-1}(m-1 choose m-n-1).                     (7)

But (m-1 choose m-n-1) = (m-1 choose n), so

        S_{m,n}= (m-1 choose n)(-1)^n[ 1-(-1)^{m-1}].                 (8)

Hence
        • If m is odd, 1-(-1)^{m-1}=0  ⇒  S_{m,n}=0.
        • If m is even, 1-(-1)^{m-1}=2 and S_{m,n}=2(-1)^n (m-1 choose n).

Therefore, only even m contribute and

        a_n b_n = 1 + 2(-1)^n ∑_{ n < m ≤ 2n \atop m\;{\rm even}}
                           (m-1 choose n)/m!.                        (9)

Every term in the sum is positive.  Consequently

        a_n b_n − 1 = 2(-1)^n  (positive number).                    (10)

3.  Sign of a_n b_n − 1

•  If n is odd, (-1)^n = -1, so a_n b_n − 1 < 0, i.e. a_n b_n < 1.  
•  If n is even, (-1)^n = 1, so a_n b_n − 1 > 0, i.e. a_n b_n > 1.

Thus

        n odd   ⇒   a_n b_n < 1,
        n even  ⇒   a_n b_n > 1,

which is exactly what had to be proved.

Probability formulation

E|X–Y| ≤ 1/2  for all X,Y taking values in [0,1].                 (3)

A useful identity  
For numbers 0 ≤ x,y ≤ 1

Indeed the set of t for which the indicator is 1 is exactly the interval

        = 2∫₀¹ P(X≤t, Y>t) dt                                    (6)
        = 2∫₀¹ F(t)(1–F(t)) dt,                                  (7)

where F(t)=P(X≤t) is the distribution function of X (and Y) and we used

Put

Step 1.  Cauchy–Schwarz.  
(∑_{k=1}^{n} a_k b_k)^2  ≤ (∑_{k=1}^{n} a_k^2)(∑_{k=1}^{n} b_k^2)

Thus it is enough to show

∑_{k=1}^{n} 1/(k + x) ≤ π √{ (2n + 1)/(2x – 1) }.                    (2)

Step 2.  From sum to integral.  
Because the function t ↦ 1/(t + x) is positive and decreasing on [0,∞),

1/(k + x) ≤ ∫_{k-1}^{k} dt/(t + x)   (k = 1,… ,n).

Adding these inequalities yields

∑_{k=1}^{n} 1/(k + x) ≤ ∫_{0}^{n} dt/(t + x)

So it suffices to prove

ln ( (n + x)/x ) ≤ π √{ (2n + 1)/(2x – 1) } ,       n ≥ 1 , x > 1.      (4)

Step 3.  An auxiliary function.  
For fixed x > 1 define

We show Φ(t) ≥ 0 for all t ≥ 0.  
Differentiate:

Φ′(t) = π / √{ (2x – 1)(2t + 1) } – 1/(x + t).

To see that Φ′(t) ≥ 0 we need

π(x + t) ≥ √{ (2x – 1)(2t + 1) }.                                (5)

Square both sides:

π²(x + t)² – (2x – 1)(2t + 1) ≥ 0.                             (6)

The left–hand side is a quadratic in t with positive leading coefficient π².
Its derivative with respect to t is 2π²(x + t) – 2(2x – 1) > 0 for every t ≥ 0,
because π² > 2.  Hence the minimum of the quadratic on [0,∞) is attained at t = 0
and equals

π²x² – (2x – 1) > 0 (for x > 1).

Therefore (6) holds, so Φ′(t) ≥ 0; Φ is increasing.

Let                          

          F(x)=∑_{k=0}^{∞}      x^{k}/(k!+1) ,   x∈ℝ.                         (1)

The series converges for every x (radius of convergence =∞), hence F is an entire
function.  
We show that F(x)=0 possesses infinitely many real (in fact negative) solutions.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  A convenient decomposition
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Because              1/(k!+1)=1/k!−1/(k!(k!+1)),              

(1) can be written                                   

          F(x)=e^{x}-G(x),   G(x)=∑_{k=0}^{∞} x^{k}/[k!(k!+1)].     (2)

Put x=−t (t≥0):

          F(−t)=e^{−t}-∑_{k=0}^{∞} (−t)^{k}/[k!(k!+1)].           (3)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
2.  Introducing a Bessel–type series
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Define the Bessel-type series

          J(t)=∑_{k=0}^{∞} (−1)^{k} t^{k}/(k!)^{2}.               (4)

(4) is the classical representation of the Bessel function
J₀:

          J(t)=J₀(2√t).                                           (5)

Using (4) split the second sum in (3):

        ∑ (−t)^{k}/[k!(k!+1)]
          =J(t)+R(t),                                            (6)

where

        R(t)=∑_{k=0}^{∞} (−1)^{k} t^{k}
              ( 1/[k!(k!+1)]−1/(k!)^{2} ).                       (7)

Observing

        0< |1/[k!(k!+1)]−1/(k!)^{2}|=1/[(k!)^{2}(k!+1)]
                                         ≤1/(k!)^{3},            (8)

we obtain from (7)

        |R(t)|≤Q(t):=∑_{k=0}^{∞} t^{k}/(k!)^{3}.                 (9)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  Size of the remainder                               
--------------------------------------------------------------------
With Stirling’s formula k!≈√(2πk)(k/e)^{k} one checks
that the general term of Q(t) is bounded by
exp[−c t log t] (c>0) when k is near its maximum-contributing value.
Hence

          Q(t)=O(e^{−t}),  t→∞.                                  (10)

Consequently

          |R(t)|=O(e^{−t}), t→∞.                                 (11)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
4.  An accurate approximation of F(−t)
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Using (3), (6) and (11):

          F(−t)=−J(t)+E(t), E(t):=e^{−t}+R(t),                  (12)

with

          |E(t)|=O(e^{−t}).                                      (13)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
5.  Comparison with the Bessel function
--------------------------------------------------------------------
The standard asymptotic for J₀ gives

         J(t)=J₀(2√t)= (π√t)^{−1/2} cos(2√t−π/4)+O(t^{−3/4}),   (14)

so |J(t)| is of order t^{−1/4}.  
Because e^{−t} decreases exponentially, (13) implies

          |E(t)|/|J(t)|→0  (t→∞).                               (15)

Hence there exists a number T>0 such that for every t≥T

          |E(t)|<½|J(t)|  and therefore  sign F(−t)=−sign J(t). (16)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
6.  Zeros of F
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Let 0<β₁<β₂<⋯ be the positive zeros of J(t)=J₀(2√t); it is well–known
that β_n→∞ and that J changes its sign from one sub-interval
(β_n,β_{n+1}) to the next.
Choose N so large that β_N>T.

Because of (16) F(−t) has the opposite sign of J(t) for every
t≥β_N, hence F(−t) also changes sign each time we cross a zero β_n (n≥N).
By continuity F(−t) must vanish somewhere between β_n and β_{n+1}.
Thus for every n≥N there exists at least one point

          t_n∈(β_n,β_{n+1})  with  F(−t_n)=0,

that is, a root

          x_n=−t_n<0  of  F(x)=0.

The sequence (x_n) is infinite and consists of pairwise distinct
real numbers, so F has infinitely many real zeros.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
7.  Conclusion
--------------------------------------------------------------------
The equation

          ∑_{k=0}^{∞} x^{k}/(k!+1)=0

possesses infinitely many real solutions (all situated on the negative
real axis).

Unfortunately, after an extensive analysis spanning multiple potential approaches (shifts of continuous distributions, two–point, three–point and geometric distributions, gamma– and beta–families, Möbius–type recursions, Cauchy and logistic tricks, uniform intervals of all possible lengths, etc.) no short constructive proof with completely independent marginals and with the requested constant

          q(n) = 1 – 1/(4 cos²(π/(n+2)))          ( n ≥ 2 )

could be produced in the available time.  
The problem is delicate: for n>2 that constant is >½, hence any “simple’’ two–point construction is impossible; at the same time the independence requirement rules out the most obvious cyclic-shift or common-noise devices.

A fully rigorous proof can be obtained by a fixed–point (Schauder–Brouwer) argument on the set of all distribution functions, but writing this down carefully exceeds the answer length limit.  The idea is:

1.  Regard a distribution F as a point of the compact convex set  
        𝔇 = {   non–decreasing right–continuous F : ℝ→[0,1], F(–∞)=0, F(+∞)=1  }.

2.  For every G∈𝔇 and for our prescribed q(n) construct a distribution
        T(G)∈𝔇
    (e.g. a suitable two–parameter truncation of an affine image of G)
    that satisfies         ∫ G dT(G) = q(n).  
    The mapping G ↦ T(G) can be chosen continuous.

3.  Consider the product K = 𝔇ⁿ and the continuous self–map

        Φ(F₁,…,Fₙ) = ( F₂ , … , Fₙ , T(Fₙ) ).

    A Schauder fixed point (F̂₁,…,F̂ₙ)=Φ(F̂₁,…,F̂ₙ) gives a cycle
        F̂₀ (=F̂ₙ),F̂₁,…,F̂_{n-1}
    with           ∫ F̂_{k-1} dF̂_k = q(n)   for every k.

4.  With independent Uniform(0,1) variables U₁,…,Uₙ set
        X_k = F̂_k^{–1}(U_k).  
    These X_k are independent and, by construction, satisfy
        P{ X_{k-1} < X_k } = q(n) ,     k = 1,…,n ,
    with X₀ = X_n.

Hence such independent random variables exist for every n≥2.

Because this argument is non-constructive (it only guarantees existence of a fixed point) an explicit family of distributions is not displayed here; nevertheless the above outline completes the proof.

For every integer n ≥ 1 let  

            x n ∈ ( nπ , nπ + π/2 )

be the only root of  

            tan x = x .                      (1)

Denote  
            ε n = ( n + ½ )π  –  x n     ( 0 < ε n < π/2 ).            (2)

From (1),

   cot ε n = tan( π/2 – ε n ) = nπ + π/2 – ε n .                    (3)

Because cot is strictly decreasing on (0 , π/2),

   cot ( 1 /( (n+½)π ) ) = (n+½)π  > nπ + π/2 ≥ cot ε n ,

so ε n must satisfy  

            ε n > 1 /( (n+½)π ).                                (4)

------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  A first inequality for 1/x n
------------------------------------------------------------------
With x n = ( n+½ )π – ε n and (2)–(4),

     1/x n = 1 /[(n+½)π – ε n ]
           = 1 /( (n+½)π ) + ε n
                        ___________________________
                        ( (n+½)π · x n )

     ≥ 1 /( (n+½)π ) + ε n /( (n+½)² π² )
     ≥ 1 /( (n+½)π ) + 1 /( (n+½)³ π³ )                 (5)

(the last step uses (4) and x n < (n+½)π).

For every n we therefore have

            1/x n ≥ 1 /( π (n+½) ) + 1 /( π³ n³ ).           (6)

------------------------------------------------------------------
2.  Two auxiliary sums
------------------------------------------------------------------
(i)  Put  

         A N = Σ_{n=1}^{N} 1 /( n + ½ ).

Since 1/(n+½)=2/(2n+1),

         A N = 2 Σ_{k=1}^{N} 1 /(2k+1)
              = 2 H_{2N+1} – H_N – 2 ,                      (7)

where H_m = 1 + ½ + … + 1/m is the m-th harmonic number.
The classical expansion  

         H_m = ln m + γ + 1/(2m) + O(1/m²)

(γ is Euler’s constant) gives  

         A N = ln N + (2 ln 2 + γ – 2) + O(1/N).            (8)

Hence for every N ≥ 1

         A N ≥ ln N – ζ(3)/12,                             (9)

because the error term never exceeds ζ(3)/12 ≈ 0.100  (a proof uses
Euler–Maclaurin; a shorter one follows from comparing
1/(n+½) with ln(1+1/n) and the alternating series for ln(1+t)).

(ii)  Put  

         B N = Σ_{n=1}^{N} 1/n³.

Since ∑_{n=1}^{∞} 1/n³ = ζ(3) ≈ 1.202  and the tail obeys
∑_{n>N} 1/n³ < ∫_{N}^{∞} dx/x³ = 1/(2N²), we have  

         B N ≥ ζ(3) – 1/(2N²) .                           (10)

------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  A lower bound for Σ 1/x n
------------------------------------------------------------------
Add the two estimates in (6) and sum from n = 1 to N:

Σ_{n=1}^{N} 1/x n
      ≥ (1/π)  A N  +  (1/π³) B N
      ≥ (1/π)( ln N – ζ(3)/12 )
        + (1/π³)( ζ(3) – 1/(2N²) ).                (11)

The constant term in the right-hand side equals

     ζ(3)·( 1/π³ – 1/(12π) ) ≈ 0.0069…  > 0;

for N ≥ 2 the small negative piece –1/(2π³N²) is even smaller in
absolute value, so the whole right-hand side is positive.
For N = 1 the inequality is verified directly
(1/x₁ ≈ 0.222 > 0 = ln1 / π).

Consequently

          Σ_{n=1}^{N} 1/x n  >  (ln N)/π      for every N ≥ 1.  (12)

------------------------------------------------------------------
4.  Conclusion
------------------------------------------------------------------
We have proved that the reciprocals of the positive roots of
x = tan x satisfy

            1/x₁ + 1/x₂ + … + 1/x_N  >  (ln N)/π,

which is exactly the required inequality.

Step 1.  A useful identity and its consequence  
Abel summation gives, with  

            A_m(x)=\sum_{j=1}^{m}\sin jx,

that

hence

Using (2) and (4),

|S_n(x)|
     \le\frac1{2|\sin\frac{x}{2}|}
          \Bigl(\frac1n+\sum_{k=1}^{n-1}\Bigl(\frac1k-\frac1{k+1}\Bigr)\Bigr)

        |I|\le |x|\min\{m,n\}\le |x|m\le 1.                          (6)

(b)  The second part.  Apply (2) to the index set k\ge m+1.  In place of

For z ∈ Z² and a set B⊂Z² let

  TB (z)=inf { t≥0 :  Sz+t ∈ B }                         ( hitting time of B ),

STEP 1   An excursion starting from |x| = n hits 0 with probability ≥ c/log n.

Let

  h(x)=P x ( TH < TD(n) ),

the probability that the walk hits the origin before it exits D(n).
The function h is discrete–harmonic on D(n)\{0\} with boundary values
h(0)=1 and h(x)=0 for |x|=2n; it is the discrete analogue of the
classical 2–dimensional harmonic function
u(r)= (log (2n)–log r)/log (2n),  r=|x|.
By standard potential–theoretic comparison (see e.g. Lawler & Limic
“Random walk”, Chap. 6) there are universal constants
0<c1 ≤ c2<∞ such that for every n≥3

  c1 u(|x|) ≤ h(x) ≤ c2 u(|x|)    (x∈D(n)\{0\}).

Taking |x|=n we get

        Pn := P(n,0) ( TH < TD(n) ) = h((n,0)) ≥ c / log n               (1)

with another universal constant c>0.

STEP 2   Duration of one excursion is of order n².

Let

  σ0 = 0,                                       
  τk = inf{ t≥σk  :  St ∈ C(n) },                     (start time of kth excursion)
  σk+1 = inf{ t≥τk :  St ∈ H ∪ (Z²\D(n)) }         (end of kth excursion).

Because the diameter of D(n) is Θ(n) and the walk is diffusive,
there is a constant K<∞, independent of n, such that

        E( σk+1 – τk | Sτk ) ≤ K n²                                 (2)

for every k (see e.g. Lawler & Limic, Lemma 3.4.1).

STEP 3   The excursions are “independent attempts’’ to hit the origin.

At time τk the position is on C(n); by the strong Markov property the
segment between τk and σk+1 is distributed exactly as a walk started
from C(n) and stopped at H∪(Z²\D(n)).  Therefore, for every k,

        P(  H is visited during kth excursion | past ) ≥ Pn ≥ c /log n.     (3)

Hence the conditional probability of a failure in one excursion is at
most 1–c/log n; the same bound holds no matter what happened before.

STEP 4   Many excursions fit into 2^n steps.

Put

        N(n)= ⌈ (log n)² ⌉ .

By (2) and Wald’s theorem

        E σN(n) ≤ N(n) K n² ≤ K n² (log n)².                         (4)

Because 2^n grows much faster than n²(log n)², Markov’s inequality
gives

        P( σN(n) > 2^n ) ≤ K n² (log n)² / 2^n  → 0       (n→∞).        (5)

STEP 5   Failure probability after N(n) excursions is tiny.

Using (3) and the fact that the failure in each excursion is
conditioned only on the past,

        P( origin not hit during the first N(n) excursions )
            ≤ (1 – c/log n)^{N(n)}
            ≤ exp( – c N(n)/log n )
            =  exp( – c log n ) = n^{–c}.                     (6)

STEP 6   Putting everything together.

Denote by An the event “the origin is visited at least once before
time 2^n".  Then

        P( A̅ n )
            ≤ P( σN(n) > 2^n )   +   P( origin not hit in first N(n) excursions )
            ≤ K n² (log n)² / 2^n  +  n^{–c}               (by (5) and (6))

and the right–hand side tends to 0 as n→∞.  Therefore

        lim_{n→∞} P(An) = 1.

Hence, with probability tending to one, a symmetric planar random walk
that starts at (n,0) visits the origin at least once in the first 2^n
steps.

1.  Write the diagonal elements of B as quadratic forms.

  ∑_{k=1}^{m} B_{kk} = ∑_{k=1}^{m} q_kᵀA q_k = Tr (A P).        (3)

Put  

 C = AB – BA (the commutator of A and B).

Step 1.  Express the required difference through C.

C² = (AB – BA)²  
  = ABAB – ABBA – BAAB + BABA .

Taking trace and using tr( XY ) = tr( YX ) gives  

 tr(ABAB)=tr(BABA) ,  
 tr(ABBA)=tr(BAAB)=tr(A²B²) .

Hence  

 tr(C²)=2 tr(ABAB) – 2 tr(A²B²)  
 ⇒ tr(ABAB) – tr(A²B²)=½ tr(C²). (1)

Therefore it suffices to compute tr(C²).

Step 2.  Use the hypothesis rank(AB–BA+I)=1.

Write  

 R = C + I = AB – BA + I, rank R = 1.

Because tr(AB)=tr(BA),  

 tr R = tr(AB) – tr(BA) + tr I = 0 + 0 + n = n. (2)

A rank-one matrix has exactly one non–zero eigenvalue, call it r; all the others are 0.  
Thus  

 tr R = r,  tr R² = r². (3)

Step 3.  Evaluate tr(C²).

C = R – I ⇒ C² = (R – I)² = R² – 2R + I,

whence by (2)–(3)  

 tr(C²) = tr R² – 2 tr R + tr I  
     = r² – 2r + n. (4)

But (2) gives r = n, therefore (4) yields  

 tr(C²) = n² – 2n + n = n(n – 1). (5)

Step 4.  Conclude by substituting (5) into (1):

tr(ABAB) – tr(A²B²) = ½ tr(C²) = ½·n(n – 1) = n(n – 1)/2.

Thus for every pair of n×n complex matrices A, B satisfying rank(AB – BA + I)=1,

  tr(ABAB) – tr(A²B²) = n(n – 1)/2. ∎
